 ESTONIA AGRICULTURE PROJECT I. BACKGROUND' A. Country Context 1.1 The Republic of Estonia lies on the Eastern shores of the Baltic Sea and shares borders with Latvia and Russia. Estonia has a territory of 45,000 square kilometers, almost the size of the Netherlands. About one third of its 1.5 million population live in rural areas. 1.2 Since regaining independence in August 1991, Estonia has followed an open and liberal reform path. It has successfully stabilized its currency, and has liberalized all agricultural commodity prices, while creating competitive markets based on minimal barriers of entry, and free internal and external trade. After declining in 1992 and 1993, real output in Estonia began to recover in 1994 and an annual growth of about 5% is projected for 1995 and 1996. The unemployment rate (adjusted for recorded jobseekers), has decreased from between 8% to 9% in 1993 to around 6% in the fourth quarter of 1995. After a sharp decline in 1992, real wages have increased broadly in line with productivity. Annual inflation has continued to decline reaching 48% in 1994 and falling further to 29% in 1995. 1.3 The recovery of output is underpinned by sound economic policies. The stability of the currency is being supported by monetary and fiscal policies consistent with the operations of the country's currency board arrangement. External trade and payments policies are liberal, with no tariff or non-tariff barriers. Sectoral policies are aimed at creating and supporting a viable private sector and the service sector in particular has developed rapidly. Privatization of former state-owned enterprises and non-land properties has nearly been completed. Urban and rural land properties are being restituted to their former owners, however, this process has been slower than expected. 1.4 Estonian agriculture contributes to economic growth and provides low-priced agricultural products for the mainly urban population. Furthermore, exports of agricultural, forestry and food products contribute significantly to total export earnings, while budget allocations to agriculture amount to less than 5% of the state budget, which is quite small in international comparison. Estonian agricultural policy- makers are committed to continuing their liberal agricultural policy and pursuing the goal of closer cooperation and eventual membership in the European Union (EU). 1.5 Agricultural Policy. In the context of the country's liberal economic and trade policy, agricultural strategy has aimed at creating an open competitive agricultural sector based on private ownership of land, a private agro-processing sector, liberal agricultural trade, fully market-determined agricultural prices, and minimal budget support for the agricultural and rural sector. Although proceeding slowly and with difficulty, Estonia has continued to restitute rural land. The privatization of agro- processing enterprises is nearly complete, and these companies are in the process of adapting to the market economy. Since 1992, agricultural prices are completely market-determined. There are no import or export tariffs regulating agricultural trade, and Estonia has entered into trade agreements with the EU and the EFTA countries, and is moving toward accession in the WTO. I Summarized from Estonia: Agriculture and Forestry Sector Review ( Report # 13316-EE, May 16, 1995).
 2 Chapter 1 1.6 Estonian agricultural policy to date can be described as exceptional within the former Soviet Union (FSU) because price and market distortions have been almost completely avoided. The single most important mechanism of Government support to the rural regions has been the establishment of a fund with budget resources to provide loans for investments in agriculture and rural enterprises. Commercial banks have used these resources to lend to agriculture and rural entrepreneurs at a capped (and therefore subsidized) interest rate. Existing interest rate subsidies to the rural economy via this credit fund2 are fully budget financed. Due to consistent and increasing pressure from the farmers' lobby to support agriculture, the Government of Estonia (GOE) intends to continue to subsidize agriculture only through the provision of credit funds from the budget with interest rate subsidies. In September 1995, the Law on Regulating the Agricultural Market was passed by Parliament to replace the previous Agricultural Market Law. The new law allows for price support payments to farmers and the imposition of import tariffs on agricultural goods but does not actually determine tariffs. However, even though the previous Agricultural Market Law allowed for price support payments to farmers, the GOE has not regulated agricultural prices or trade in the past, and is committed to continue this open market policy in the future. 1.7 Estonia is embarking on the next stage of improving rural institutions after having nearly completed the transition to a market economy with minimal market distortions. Unlike other countries of the former Soviet Union, the GOE has a well developed agricultural sector policy, and is now in a position to effectively use public investments to rehabilitate rural infrastructure (including the deteriorating farm drainage systems), promote the transfer to private ownership, improve agricultural technology dissemination to the evolving private farms, promote rural entrepreneurship, and strengthen the sector's public institutions. B. Agriculture 1.8 Throughout its history, agriculture was the most significant activity of the Estonian economy. Main export products were processed agricultural goods such as eggs, butter, cheese and flax, and raw materials such as timber. The Soviet annexation in 1940 had a profound effect on the country's economy through the elimination of private property, the collectivization of agriculture, and the incorporation of Estonia into the Union-wide command system. Estonia was assigned the role of a specialized livestock producer, and supplied dairy products, pork, and beef to neighboring republics, which in turn, provided most of the grain and other needed inputs. Animal products accounted for more than two thirds of the total value of agricultural production, and crop production was oriented mainly towards roughage. The large agricultural trade surplus was based on heavily subsidized supplies of inputs and feed from the other republics of the FSU. 1.9 Post-independence agriculture in Estonia is dominated by dairy and livestock production. Even though livestock production has decreased considerably during the transition period, this sector presents the highest competitive potential for Estonian agriculture. Crop production focuses on feed grains and fodder crops for the livestock sector. In 1994 the sector accounted for about 9% of GDP, contributed 15% of exports, and employed about 6% of the Estonian labor force. It is estimated that agricultural production decreased by about 40% from 1991 to 1993, resulting in a similar contraction of the agricultural labor force. The food processing industry is characterized by over-capacities but, after restructuring, is expected to contribute significantly to GDP. 2 The mission estimates the implicit annual rural credit subsidy to amount to US $1.0 million to date.
 Estonia Agriculture Project 3 1.10 Exports. Although agricultural production has declined sharply, the export of agricultural and food products has not declined to the same extent. Even though Estonia is a net exporter of meat and dairy products, the trade surplus for these products has been declining, and future agricultural export opportunities are not open-ended. Russia, the traditional customer, has imposed import tariffs on Estonian agricultural products, yet agricultural exports to Russia continue to be of major importance, accounting for 54% of total agricultural exports at the beginning of 1995. Other potential customers, such as the EU, limit imports on the one hand through tariff barriers, and on the other hand, by their demand for high quality and health standards for imported agricultural products. .11 Food Demand. Consumption of meat and dairy products in Estonia has dropped since independence from previously high levels. The cause is the decrease in real incomes of Estonian consumers who have substituted relatively cheaper cereals and potatoes for the more expensive livestock products. The combination of declines in local consumption of livestock products and increases in low cost or better quality imports of agricultural and food products from neighboring countries, continues to contribute to the contraction of the agricultural sector. 1.12 Farm Structure3. Before independence agricultural production was organized in 350 large cooperatives, each managing some 3,500 ha with roughly 300 employees each. Nearly all of the assets of state and collective farms have been privatized since independence. The farming structure has been developing towards smaller sized family farms with an average size of 24 ha. Presently, the farm structure is characterized by three different types of farms: (a) about 3,500 "legal enterprises" (joint stock companies, partnerships, and co-operatives) which emerged from the former sovkhozes and kolkhozes (collective farms) now on about 70% of total agricultural land. The joint stock companies do not own land, the land either belongs to the members, or is rented from the state. Often these enterprises have only a transitional character and are dividing into smaller entities as the privatization process continues and shareholders prefer to take their land and set up their own, private, farms. Further contraction of these large-scale enterprises is expected over the next 18 to 24 months. (b) about 10.000 - 15,000 family farms with an average area of about 24 ha (17% of the total agricultural lands). It is expected that the number of family farms will increase in the near future (of these, only about 25% have registered their land titles). (c) more than 130,000 small, and non-registered, subsidiary plots, with an average area of 1.7 ha, often used by the shareholders of the large farming structures, to supplement their wage income. 1.13 It can be expected that joint-stock farms will continue to down-size because members wishing to start their own farms will withdraw their restituted land from the joint stock companies. The number of private family farms will increase, and a larger share of rural income will be generated through off-farm and non-farm activities as growth and employment opportunities in other sectors of the economy increase. Some private farms will increase in size, whereas for others, land resource endowments will be 3 Information provided by the MOA. Due to the rapid transition of the farming sector, estimates of farm numbers and land shares are changing rapidly, and do not necessarily correspond to other Government statistics.
 4 Chapter I inadequate for full-time farming and will need to be supplemented by off-farm income. Farm model calculations (Annex 3) show that Estonian farms on good soils could compete internationally, especially in dairy and beef production, if production efficiency was marginally increased (new techniques and rehabilitated drainage), access to adequate credit was improved, input supplies and qualified extension advice were secured, and quality and marketing of processed agricultural products was improved. 1.14 Livestock and Crop Production. Dairy production has traditionally been, and remains, the major activity of the agricultural sector. However, it has also declined considerably since independence. Beef meat production has declined even faster than dairy production due to its low profitability. Because of climatic conditions, cereal production has never been of great importance and has continued to decrease overall in the recent years. While the area planted with wheat and rye has increased slightly, barley production, which is mainly used as animal feed, has decreased considerably. 1.15 As FSU markets have become less accessible and the supply of subsidized grain for animal feeding has been withdrawn, herd owners have started to reduce production costs by placing more reliance on pastures as a feed source. However, pastures have not been improved and managed in order to achieve high yields and quality, and the milk yield per cow has dropped from an average of around 4,000 kg/year to around 3,600 kg/year since independence. Only 23% of pastures contain legumes, and part of the grasslands used for livestock feeding are in effect abandoned croplands containing a mix of volunteer grasses and weeds. They will eventually reach the stage where they will no longer support livestock production. Nevertheless low-cost technologies to increase milk and beef production and rehabilitate pastures are available in Estonia and these are now being adopted successfully by a small number of farmers. 1.16 Drainage. Historically, drainage has been a very significant element in maintaining the productivity of both arable lands and those under forest cover. Drainage systems regulate the depth (below surface) of the groundwater table and moisture of the soils during critical periods, thereby lengthening the growing season and increasing crop and pasture yields. On areas where natural drainage is inadequate, artificial drainage systems can extend the growing season for about a month by ensuring that the groundwater table can be maintained at least 40 cm below surface. Well drained lands can be planted earlier and harvested later, as waterlogging can be avoided and fields would be dry enough for farm machinery to operate. Rehabilitation of drainage systems is an important prerequisite to increasing crop and pasture production. 1.17 Of the 1.12 million ha of total arable land, some 739,000 ha or 66% are drained artificially. Routine maintenance of the drainage systems since independence has dropped dramatically in most systems, due to constraints on the GOE's budget, to the point where permanent damage to the system (e.g. plugging of tile drains) will be unavoidable in the near future unless proper operation and maintenance (O&M) measures are revived. Much of the drain systems, particularly the sub-surface systems covering 643,000 ha of the arable area, are now not functioning at full capacity. Additionally, the drainage undertaken in the Soviet period was done without proper environmental assessment. Any future investments in drainage rehabilitation will therefore need to undergo careful environmental assessment. 1.18 Drainage is primarily the responsibility of the Land Amelioration Unit (LAU) of the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA). LAU's twelve county-level Amelioration Bureaux (ABs) are presently responsible for O&M on all the drainage and polder schemes in their localities. A Land Amelioration Law which regulates the organization of Land and Water Associations (LWAs) was adopted by the Estonian
 Estonia Agriculture Project 5 Parliament in April 1994.4 This law focuses on the privatization of drainage systems to individual fanmers and on the establishment of LWAs. Membership in LWAs is compulsory for all farmers benefitting from drainage systems. Following a transitional period, the LWAs are expected to take over the operation and maintenance of their location-schemes from the county-ABs. 1.19 Repair and reconstruction of the drainage system was funded by the GOE with EEK 5.8 million in 1994, and in 1995 for EEK 10.3 million. A full national drainage rehabilitation program would require massive budgetary resources, but the operational feasibility and economic justification of such a massive program is questionable. Over 50% of the total areas of drained farmland have been classified as lands of poor fertility. These areas, whether drainage is well maintained or not, do not have the crop yield potential that would meet the thresholds for profitable farming under present cropping patterns and open market economy input/output prices. Therefore, the Project would selectively finance drainage rehabilitation only on the most fertile soils and would not finance any new drainage of agricultural lands or forests. 1.20 Asriculture Extension Services. About 700 full and part-time agricultural advisors are employed in the private sector (e.g. veterinarians, advisors from the processing industries, private consultants, input suppliers); the public sector (e.g. staff from universities or colleges, research institutes, county-based staff of the MOA); the media (mostly specialized press); and by the farmers themselves (e.g. Farmers' Union with about 150 advisors, the Producers' Union, and farmers' circles). The present level of public funding for extension is low, representing about 0.05% of the agricultural GDP whereas many countries invest about I to 2% of agricultural GDP in extension. The MOA has decided to provide a large part of the advisory services to the potentially more profitable farmers on a "for pay" basis, through a private advisory system, while maintaining a small public advisory service to be available to farmers who do not have the means to pay for advice. Rural information centers, which have been created in many rural areas, assist with advice on off-farm job opportunities and rural entrepreneurship. 1.21 The extension service in the former Soviet Union was highly specialized and aimed at servicing state and collective farms and ensuring the adherence to delivery of centrally planned production targets. The advisors did not provide any business or market-related advice. The extension service now requires retraining and re-orientation to provide advice relevant to an open market economy. The emerging farmers lack business experience, and need advice on production techniques, agricultural economics and farm management, while the managers of the profitable larger farms need advice on staff management, marketing, and financial management. Several donor-financed technical assistanceprograms have already been established in Estonia and are training agricultural advisors. In addition, EU (Phare), as complementary support to this Project, has recently started a technical assistance program to train agricultural advisors and to develop private agricultural advisory services. 1.22 Research. Research was highly centralized in the pre-independence period, but is now being conducted at three levels. Universities undertake academic research, while applied research is the responsibility of the Academy of Science and of the independent State research institutions and laboratories. Research at all levels is severely constrained by a shortage of funds, and requires reorientation to market-responsive production systems based on economic priorities. 4 Other laws reguating the finctions of LWAs include: Land Amelioration Law (1994); Law on Associations (1992); Business Law (1995); and the Wiaer Law (1994).
 6 Chapter I C. Agro-Enterpnses 1.23. Aero-Processing. Most of the Estonian agro-processing (milk, meat, and grain enterprises) have been privatized and sold, mainly to cooperatives, some of which have foreign investors. Small scale activities have been successfully privatized, and several new enterprises have been established. Given the high level of (nominal) overcapacity, technical deficiencies, and financial problems facing the large-scale agro-processing enterprises, and the legacy of the export orientation to the FSU, significant decommissioning of installed but out-of-date capacity, and upgrading of the remaining capacity, is required to adequately transform these industries into efficient producers of the range and quality of products acceptable in Estonia's future markets. 1.24 Food Ouality Control. Present laboratories and their personnel are not equipped and trained to meet international requirements in food quality control. The GOE plans to adjust quality control measures and standards to meet EU food import standards, to enhance producers' export potential to the EU and to other countries, and also to protect the health of domestic consumers. The trade agreement between Estonia and the EU stipulates that Estonian agricultural exports must meet EU standards and that the products be free of various contaminants and potentially harmful residues. Therefore, monitoring and testing capacities need to be established to evaluate and ensure a high quality of food and livestock products to exploit Estonia's export opportunities. 1.25 SuPDlY services have been improving since 1993 and agricultural input and machinery can be purchased through dealers from the world market. Private farmers often depend on machinery services from cooperatives, but their old Soviet machinery is outdated and will have to be replaced soon. New arrangements, such as farmers' machine cooperatives, could provide the necessary services to small farmers. D. Land Reform 1.26 Land Reform. The total area of agricultural land and forest to be privatized is estimated at 2.3 million hectares (including natural grass land, arable land, orchards, and forests) out of the total Estonian land area of 4.5 million hectares. The reform of land ownership, (i.e., restoration of personal property rights and the sale or lease of state lands) is a central element of Estonia's economic reform. This also implies a reorganization of the collective farms. The Government recognizes that rural land reform is the key element for rural economic transformation. The actual process of formally transferring ownership to the newly established private farms has been slower than desirable. The approach chosen for land reform - restitution based on pre-1940 boundaries - seems to be the most significant factor in slowing down land privatization, and creating uncertainties as to the right of the cultivators. Many land owners not involved in agriculture have chosen alternative lands or non-land compensation, in place of accepting the restitution of their actual "ancestral lands." Consequently, a significant proportion of the arable and forest land remains under State ownership at the end of the first stage of land restitution. 1.27 Despite the importance attached by the GOE to land reform and privatization, only 13% of eligible rural lands (300,000 ha) have been devolved to private control (including restituted land, and land transferred under the Farm Law Act of 1989). As of December 1995, about 220,000 ha (privately and state-owned land) have been registered in the cadastre, and about 180,000 ha have been registered in the Title Book. The slow progress of the land reform can be attributed to the difficulties in adjusting the legal framework to handle high transaction volumes under restitution, insufficient institutional capacity and lack of coordination between local cadastre centers (under the Land Board), title book offices (under
 Estonia Agriculture Project 7 the Ministry of Justice), municipalities, notaries, and the GOE's limited financial resources to complete the land surveys and registration. 1.28 After completing land restitution, market forces will govern the disposal, utilization, and price of land. The land reform process has, however, created complex questions about the disposal of state owned arable and productive land, and the establishment and facilitation of private land markets. An important task for the GOE is to work out a policy for the transfer of ownership of state-owned lands in the rural areas into private hands. Maintenance and management of parks and protected areas established after 1940, which include former private agricultural lands, create further problems. 1.29 The GOE has initiated several actions to accelerate land reform and ownership transfers, including: the devolution of land reform authority to municipalities; plans to simplify land registration procedures; replacement of the Land Board management; the limiting of the Land Board's functions to quality control over the municipalities and private surveyors' cadastre activities; and strengthening the capacity of the land and title book registration offices to handle the large number of land and title registrations. In 1995, the GOE has transferred state cadastre functions from the state agency Est-Survey to the Land Board and plans to completely privatize Est-Survey's commercial land survey activities by mid-1996. County Land Cadastre Offices have been established in nearly all counties. The GOE has also recently established a Land Reform Commission consisting of representatives of the Ministries of Justice, Agriculture, and Environment, the Land Board, and members of Parliament, to coordinate land policy, develop suggestions to speed up the land registration process, and to simplify procedures and regulations. Legislation approved by the Estonian Parliament in 1995 assigns up to 100% of the land tax to local governments and gives local governments greater authority over land titling and registration. Municipalities are now authorized to sell state owned land (without pending restitution claims) and can retain some of the sales proceeds to accelerate their work. The GOE has allocated about EEK 73 million (US $6.6 million) in the budget for 1996 to carry out land reform. E. Rural Finance 1.30 The Estonian commercial banking system is inadequate,5 in relation to the size of the economy, despite the relatively large number of independent banks. The Estonian banking system has been privatized6 and, in the process, has gone through major restructuring and consolidation. Yet, there are still too many banks for the overall economy, and further bank consolidation and restructuring is expected as the Bank of Estonia continues to tighten its requirements. 1.31 The GOE has established a large number of funds to channel budget resources through commercial banks to various sectors, including agriculture, rural enterprises, and housing. In 1993, the GOE established three funds -- the Agriculture and Rural Life Credit Fund (ARLCF), the Small and Medium Enterprise Fund, and the Export Credit Fund that finance credit to agriculture. The finances of these funds are derived solely from the GOE's budget and loans from these funds are exclusively channeled through commercial banks. Up to December 1994, about EEK 200 million had been on-lent from ARLCF to commercial banks and then to farners and rural enterprises. The Government allocated 5 A more complete discussion can be found in the Financial Institutions Development Project (Report #6376-EE). 6 Even though the State remains a significant shareholder in a number of banks.
 8 apter I an additional EEK 91 million to ARLCF in 1995. Seventy-eight percent of the loans have been made for agricultural activities, the majority directly for agricultural production. Up to 1995, the implicit annual rural credit subsidy has been estimated by the appraisal mission to be about US $1.0 million. 1.32 The GOE plans to consolidate the large number of funds into one Regional Development Fund and to allocate an additional EEK 100 million to this Fund in 1996. Although the GOE has not fully developed the mechanism, it is anticipated that the funds would be on-lent to commercial banks and then to farmers (about EEK 60 million). In addition, the Fund would finance interest rate subsidies (about EEK 40 million) to cover the difference between commercial bank's market interest rates charged for loans to agricultural producers and their interest rates charged to long-term borrowers in other sectors. This would increase the rural credit subsidy planned for 1996 to US $4 million. The Government is fully apprised of the impact of this subsidy, both on the budget and the banking system. However, it believes such costs are acceptable relative to the negative economic impacts of the full protectionist support the farming community would like to receive. F. Environment 1.33 There is both a strong political commitment to, and a strong public awareness of, environmental issues, including support for environment non-governmental organizations (NGOs) activity. Estonia has inherited a number of serious environmental problems from the FSU, most of which relate to pollution from heavy industry, ex-military sites, and urban waste disposal. Estonia has demonstrated its commitment to the environment through its participation in multilateral efforts on the Baltic Sea, its own and Bank-sponsored environment-related investments to support this amelioration effort,7 and ongoing discussions with the Bank for additional environment-related investments. A draft overview of environmental issues in Estonia is being prepared by the Bank. In addition, the Bank is assisting in the preparation of a "Biodiversity Strategy" financed through the Global Environmental Facility (GEF). Under the District Heating Rehabilitation Project, the GOE took a significant step in reducing air pollution, through its examination and adoption of alternative fuels and clean combustion methods. 1.34 Environmental legislation in Estonia exists and is being revised and augmented. The current transitional status is characterized by a combination of the administrative procedures, legislation, and standards used when Estonia was part of the Soviet Union, and some new provisions stipulated by the GOE. Estonia's Basic Law on Nature and Environment Protection was passed in 1990. This has been augmented by the recent passage of important laws and regulations regarding hazardous waste, solid waste, environmental impact assessment (EIA), and natural resource pollution taxes. The Ministry of Environment (MOE) is responsible for review of EIAs when proposed projects are of national significance, while County Environment Departments (CEDs) are responsible for the EIA of projects of local significance. The MOE, with outside assistance, is working to improve the quality of ETA oversight. Training is also being provided to specialists from line ministries, commercial banks and consulting firms, in the preparation and use of ELAs in project design and implementation. 1.35 Pre-independence agriculture, primarily because of the concentration of large livestock numbers in large farm complexes, caused localized (point-source), and in some cases significant, pollution of soil and water resources. Drainage constructed during this period for expansion of agriculture and 7 For example, the Haapsalu and Matsalu Bays Environment Project (Report #13907-EE, April 25, 1995).
 Estonia Agriculture Project 9 development of peat resources had a broad range of environmentally adverse impacts. Past over-use of fertilizers and pesticides has also been reported. These problems can be avoided through the use of proper environmental review procedures and adoption of mitigation actions. The decline in agricultural production since independence, combined with the steep relative price increases of chemical inputs, has reduced the previously high pollution loads. The decline in livestock populations, and their dispersal into small units, has decreased the point-source pollution, but could result in more dispersed pollution if livestock operations are not managed with adequate environmental safeguards (e.g. safe storage and limited application of manure, etc.). Agricultural run-off, particularly to protected coastal areas and nature reserves could cause environmental damages if mitigation measures are not enforced. G. Bank Strategy and Experience in Estonia 1.36 Countrv Assistance Strategy. The key objective of the Bank's assistance strategy for Estonia is to support development of a dynamic private sector, improve the existing public infrastructure, and alleviate the pockets of poverty that have developed during the transition process, in order to raise overall living standards. To achieve the objectives, the Bank's program is focused on two main areas: (a) improving the environment for private sector investment and growth; (b) improving public infrastructure services. 1.37 For agriculture, the Government has welcomed the Bank's support during the sector's difficult transition to a market economy, which requires an agricultural sector based on private ownership of rural land, enterprises, and farms, and competitive open markets, privatization of farm drainage infrastructure, and effective public sector agencies to support private sector development in the rural areas. The agricultural sector is of special importance to the Bank's strategy of supporting privatization in the economy and specifically in the emerging rural private sector. This Project would support accelerating the land reform, improving food quality control measures and standards to meet EU requirements, improving rural human resource skills through public and private advisory services, upgrading and increasing efficiency of farm drainage infrastructure and its privatization and transfer to the systems' beneficiary groups. 1.38 Lessons Learned from Previous Bank Experience. Previous Bank involvement in project implementation has included a 1992 Rehabilitation Loan (US $30.0 million, completely disbursed and now closed), a Highway Maintenance Loan for US $12 million in 1994, a District Heating Rehabilitation Loan for US $38.4 million in 1994, a Health Project in 1995 for US $18 million, a Financial Institutions Development Project in 1995 for US $10 million (all effective and under implementation), and the recently approved Haapsalu and Matsalu Bays Environment Project (April 25, 1995). Experience in implementing these projects has shown that it is important in the initial stages of project implementation to fully train the Project Implementation Unit (PIU) staff in project management, financial management, and competitive procurement procedures. In general, implementation of projects in Estonia has been satisfactory. Consequently, a joint PIU would be responsible to assist the implementation of the Bank's, EU (Phare)'s and other donor programs in agriculture and the staff would be trained in management, procurement, and monitoring & evaluation.

Rationale for Bank Involvement 1.39 The Bank has assisted the GOE in the development of its sector strategy through the preparation of this Project and the preparation and discussions of the Agriculture and Forestry Sector Review. This review highlights key strategy elements for the development of the sector: efficiency improvements in primary agricultural production; development of agricultural advisory services; agricultural marketing improvements; and rapid completion of land reform. The Sector Review notes that low wages, low land costs, and the existing stock of skills, equipment, and productive infrastructure provide Estonia with a competitive potential in dairy and beef production. This competitiveness has already been demonstrated on a limited scale by some transformed farms and food processing industries. The Sector Review discussions with the GOE stressed the need for an open agricultural economy, land privatization, and the reorientation and strengthening of public and private agricultural services. In general, the GOE's agricultural policy reflects these objectives, although progress has been difficult in some areas during the transition period. 1.40 Rural and Agricultural Strategy. The GOE actively supports the development of the rural areas in order to narrow the income gap between urban and rural populations. The main objective of the GOE is to transform and improve living conditions in the rural sector, primarily through accelerating rural land reform and supporting agricultural and rural entrepreneurship activities. A key issue of this strategy is the association and anticipated future membership of Estonia in the European Union. Developing an agricultural policy aligned with the EU would therefore be central to the activities of the MOA in the future, and the GOE is in the process of developing and refining its agricultural policies to reflect this. 1.41 The MOA has proposed to the Cabinet a set of polices and strategies. These strategies includes the following key elements: * acceleration of the land reform by simplifying procedures for land registration, and by initiating the sale or lease of land that has not been claimed by former owners and is under state control; * improved marketing of agricultural products through improved market transparency and by adjusting quality control measures and standards to meet EU requirements; * improved rural financial services to provide farmers and rural entrepreneurs with long-term credit funds coupled with advisory services for borrowers and banks; * revision of the tax policy to create equal tax conditions for agriculture; * development of an efficient agricultural advisory service to promote structural and technological changes in agricultural production and land use; and * development and rehabilitation of rural infrastructure in areas with a low population density. 1.42 Bank Support. The Bank supports the MOA's strategy to ease key bottlenecks in the agricultural sector, primarily by accelerating the land reform, improving the maintenance of rural infrastructure (drainage), developing the agricultural advisory services, and improving the food quality control. The Project would therefore strengthen the private sector, improve the MOA's policy and regulatory functions, and support a gradual transfer of non-essential Government functions to the private
 Estonia Agriculture Project 11 sector. The Project investments support key Government regulatory functions (food quality control, environmental regulation in agriculture) and the gradual transfer of some government functions to the private sector (land reform, drainage maintenance, advisory services). The Project assists the MOA in rehabilitating and privatizing farm drainage infrastructure by handing over the responsibility for future operation and maintenance to the beneficiaries. Furthermore, the Project supports the development of a private farner-financed advisory service to complement a basic Government funded, modestly-sized, agricultural extension service. These are investments of either a public good dimension, or necessary to support the emerging private sector and reduce recurrent Govermment expenditures. 1.43 The Bank had intended to support the rural sector with investments in rural credit and forestry. However the GOE, after consultations with the Bank, and for reasons discussed below, has decided not to use loan funds from this Project for these priority areas. 1.44 The GOE plans to streamline support to agriculture and the rural areas through a Regional Development Fund providing loan funds (for on-lending through commercial banks) and interest rate subsidies for regional development, including agriculture. The GOE's policy is to continue to provide this limited budget support to develop a viable private farming sector and to re-capitalize the emerging farms. The Regional Development Fund (with interest rate subsidies) is seen by the GOE and the MOA as a second best alternative, but it allows the Government to continue support for an open market policy in agriculture. The Ministry of Finance judges that the distortion of the financial sector is small in comparison to distortions that would be created by agricultural price support payments or an introduction of significant agricultural import tariffs. Considering the high liquidity in the financial system and the Government policy to subsidize interest rates, Bank lending for rural finance would not be appropriate at this time. 1.45 For forestry sector investments, the GOE and the Bank have agreed during Project preparation that the finalization of a Strategic Plan for Forestry (and related studies) should be a prerequisite for determining future public expenditures in forestry. Assistance to the GOE for the preparation of this plan, and the studies, is now being donor financed (see Annex 1).
 II. THE PROJECT A. Project Origin and Formulation 2.1 Estonia has followed a liberal reform path: these reforms have successfully initiated economic transformation. Whereas the liberal reform policy has been quite successful in the urban areas, with wage incomes beginning to rise there, the reforms in rural areas have not shown similar levels of success. This is mainly due to the slow progress of the land reform and the reorientation of agricultural exports to western markets. The new Government is strongly committed to supporting development of the rural areas and to narrowing the income gap between urban and rural populations. 2.2 The intent of the GOE and the Bank was to prepare a program of loan and grant supported interventions (investments and technical assistance) to address agriculture and forestry productivity, rural entrepreneurship and finance, rural infrastructure, rural land use management and related environment issues, and land reform. During the course of project preparation by the GOE and the Bank, a number of items were removed from the scope of the Project as they were either fully taken over by donor supported technical assistance (forestry, rural entrepreneurship, rural finance -- Annex 1), or the GOE decided not to borrow for investments (rural infrastructure other than drainage, and rural finance), but instead to fund these from budget resources. 2.3 The Project supports the agricultural strategy through selected investments in farm drainage rehabilitation, land use management, food quality control, and agricultural advisory services, supported by the GOE's land reform budget. The components of this Project were designed by the MOA and the MOE with bilateral', EU (Phare)2 and Bank3 assistance commencing October 1993. This report reflects the outcome of the Bank's consultations with the GOE beginning with Project identification (February 1994), followed by Project preparation missions (October 1994 and January 1995), appraisal (June 1995) and included working groups to prepare the Project Implementation Plans (see Annexes - Volume 2). Policy elements were extensively discussed with the GOE in a public review of the Agriculture Sector Review in January 1995. B. Detailed Project Description4 Land Reform (US $5.5 million)5 2.6 To accelerate the land reform, this component provides financing for the completion of the National Geodetic Network; land survey works; and of a state rural land disposal study. Under separate arrangements, donor-funded projects provide technical assistance to strengthen the institutional and technical capacities of the Estonian National Land Board (ENLB), and land registration agencies. 2.7 National Geodetic Network. The Component would support the completion of a nation- wide ground control network which coordinates all measured boundaries into one unified system. Over a period of 3 years, 5,000 points would be measured by private surveying companies using GPS technology. 2.8 Cadastral Surveying. This component would finance surveying and cadastre registration of about 150,000 ha of rural lands over 5 years. This is equivalent to about 6,000 farmns of different sizes. The surveys will be primarily carried out in the drainage rehabilitation areas financed under the Project to complete the registration of agricultural land in the cadastre. The GOE would recover the costs of the surveys from private land owners at a later stage. At negotiations, an agreement was reached that by June 30, 1996, the cadastre registration of Est-Survey (a state-owned surveying company) shall be transferred to the National Land Board (para 5.1 (a)). As a condition of disbursement, the Borrower shall have: published the tender for privatization of at least five of Est-Survey's regional land survey offices or terminated Est-Survey's commercial land survey activities; and contracted all publicly-funded land and property surveys to private surveyors under competitive bidding procedures (para 5.4 (a)). 2.9 State-Owned Rural Lands Disposal Policy. The Government would initiate studies to analyze possibilities to lease and sell rural land under state ownership, to streamline land transfer procedures, to clarify the rights and responsibilities of local governments, and to determine incentives for title book registration. The study would also address the issue of future ownership of former private lands which were designated and managed as "protected" areas during the Soviet period. By March 31, 1996, the GOE would initiate studies, acceptable to the Bank; to formulate a national policy for the transfer of State-owned rural andfarming lands to private ownership, and publish and present to the Bank a plan for the development of such policy, including a timetable for its technical analysis and adoption, and, by March 31, 1997, its implementation, taking into consideration the Bank's views (para 5.1 (b)). Farm Drainage Rehabilitation (US $10.9 million) 2.11 The drainage rehabilitation component would consist of: (a) rehabilitation of drainage systems; (b) development of Land and Water Associations (LWAs); and (c) development of an adaptive drainage research program. 2.12 Rehabilitation of drainage systems. The Project plans to rehabilitate about 60,000 ha of drained agricultural land in about 60 separate locations. This component would rehabilitate main channels and collector drains, flush and repair subsurface pipe outlets entering collector drains, and selectively till compacted soils as a complement to site-specific drainage improvement. 2.13 Drainage Site Selection Criteria. Areas for drainage rehabilitation works would be selected according to site selection criteria7 that include: (a) environmental screening; (b) soil fertility; (c) land use intensity; (d) condition of the drainage systems; (e) technical feasibility and designs; (f) investment cost ceiling; (g) status of land tenure;8 (h) farmer's participation, including formation of LWAs; (i) commitment of LWA members to contribute to rehabilitation costs and take over future operation and maintenance of the system; and (j) location of markets. Most (95%) of the state-owned agricultural land would be sold or leased (minimum 10 year lease contracts) prior to commencement of the drainage rehabilitation works9. Special screening criteria would be used for any proposed activities in the catchment area of the Matsalu Bay because of the ecological importance of the Matsalu State Nature Reserve. Project financed drainage investments would be limited to rehabilitation works and investments would not be made for new drainage schemes and would not include polders'0 or "wet forests." Assurances have been sought at negotiations from the GOE that investments in rehabilitation would be made only on those sites that fully meet the above mentioned selection criteria (para 5. 1 (c)). A parallel technical assistance program is currently being sought by the Institute for possible international collaboration and exchange in this field. 2.18 Cost Recovery. The GOE plans to privatize the ownership, operations and maintenance of all farm drainage systems by handing over these systems to LWAs after completion of the drainage rehabilitation works. Responsibilities of LWAs are specified in the Amelioration Law (May 1994) and membership is compulsory for farmers in the drainage area. The GOE has determined that each LWA must agree to contribute (in cash or in kind) 20% of the cost of the rehabilitation works (the remaining 80% would be covered by the GOE with budget and Project loan funds). In return, the GOE would, post- rehabilitation, no longer accept any further financial responsibility for these on-farm drainage systems. The cost sharing formula is a legal decision of the GOE and based on an estimated average payment capacity by the beneficiaries. The GOE decided to cover the majority of the one time rehabilitation costs because thereafter each LWA would take-over full ownership of its area-specific drainage system and bear the full future O&M and rehabilitation costs.'6 However, the ABs would continue to be responsible for operations and maintenance of rivers and main canals outside the drainage areas, as the main canals often serve other users such as industries and municipalities. Cost recovery options for maintenance of rivers and main canals are being considered, including the possibility of: (a) direct charges to landowners; and (b) transferring the financial responsibility of this maintenance to the respective municipalities which would then recover these costs through local taxes. At negotiations, an agreement was reached that the members of the L WA benefiting from the Project's drainage rehabilitation shall contribute 20% of the costs of the drainage rehabilitation works either in cash or by providing labor (para 5. 1 (e)). 2.19 Public Investment Program for Related Rural Infrastructure. The GOE has allocated significant sums in the Public Investment Program for 1995-1997 for rural infrastructure improvement.'7 The GOE would ensure that the necessary rural infrastructure upgrading, currently planned under the Public Investment Program, would be provided at the locations of the participating LWAs as a complement to their improved drainage systems. I. Poverty Impact 2.51 Since independence, Estonia has moved rapidly towards a market economy. During the transition period, the living standard for segments of the population have declined as the costs of living have increased faster than average wages. The transition period has been especially severe on the rural population and the rural population is among those with the highest probability of becoming poor. Since the situation in Estonia is changing rapidly, only limited and piecemeal information is available on rural poverty. Project beneficiaries (the rural population), have a significantly larger proportion of poor people than the population as a whole. However, the current restructuring of agriculture has had a negative impact for some segments of the rural population. 2.52 The following differential impacts may be seen: (a) Rural Unemployment. Employment in the agriculture sector has declined from around 100,000 to about 30,000 from 1991 to 1994 but this decline seems to have lessened. Some of the redundant farm laborers might have found jobs in the expanding service sector, but many have to depend on seasonal or part-time employment, and on the products of their household plots until the rural job market improves. The Project actively pursues the creation of rural jobs and off-farm employment through it's various components. (b) Farmers in areas with good agricultural potential would benefit as the project components specifically support the development of economically viable farms. However, it is expected that farmers in marginal areas would not benefit from the on-farm investments in drainage rehabilitation but would have access to the rural advisory services to identify potential alternative off-farm income sources. (c) Urban and Rural Consumers would benefit from the project as food products continue to be produced at or below world market prices, on efficient and unsubsidized farms. Lower food prices would directly benefit the poorer segments of the population. 2.53 The Project would support policies that deliberately target the viable agricultural sector and might therefore negatively affect a number of farm workers. However, the support to the rural economy would increase off-farm employment and rural job opportunities. Furthermore, the benefits of the reform policy accruing to the majority of the rural and the urban population clearly outweigh the short- term costs. In the long run, the reform policies of the GOE supported by the Agriculture Project would create a competitive and productive rural sector that provides jobs and improves incomes for the rural population, and is not dependent on income transfers from taxpayers or consumers.
 28 Chapter I J. Gender and Family Issues 2.54 The need for a specific loan component to address gender issues was evaluated during project preparation and not seen as necessary. Men and women in Estonia have equal rights to land ownership. Women share responsibility in the rural sector in Estonia, including, for example, management responsibilities in large farm organizations, and political leadership for rural municipalities. The breakup of large collective farms is expected to create more family operated farms and businesses. The social network of many of the former collective farming structures, such as child care and community activities has been partly taken over by the municipalities. Downsizing of the agricultural sector may result in a lack of employment opportunities for the younger and the older generation -in the rural areas. The Government therefore plans to target support (outside of the Project) directly to these groups in the rural areas.

 IV. BENEFITS AND RISKS A. Benefits and Justification' 4.1 The major benefits are: * accelerated development of a rural land market; * increased agricultural production and farm income in the drainage rehabilitation areas; * improved farmers' information on new farming technologies and management practices; * development of grassroots rural institutions; * improved food and livestock quality standards to protect consumers and increase export potential of food and livestock products to the EU; * protection of the environment through environmental controls in agriculture, drainage, and wetlands management; and * revitalization and development of farms, services and enterprises that would create additional employment opportunities in rural areas. 4.2 Country and Agricultural Strategv. The Project supports the GOE's strategy to transform the rural sector, through support of private agricultural and rural initiatives, into an economically viable and competitive market-based system. The Project selectively provides investments to improve existing key infrastructure in target areas (farm drainage rehabilitation), strengthens the public agricultural extension service and supports the development of private agricultural advisors, and enhances food quality control functions. The Project focuses on investments that initiate a gradual transfer of Government functions to the private sector (advisory services, drainage maintenance), or improve core Government functions (food quality control, public advisory services, environmental controls in agriculture). 4.3 Scope of the Analysis and Summary Results. The financial and economic analysis is divided into two sections: (a) The financial and economic farm model analysis of the profitability of crop and livestock production, which shows an estimated ERR of 16% (the farm model analysis shows that the Project investments in drainage rehabilitation and private extension, if complemented by privately financed on-farm investments in farm assets, would increase farm incomes by 40% after two years compared to a situation without Project); (b) the major economic benefits and the expected impact of the Project investments on Government expenditures of each component are analyzed, partially using cost- effectiveness analysis. I The Economic and Financial Analysis of the Project is described in detail in Annex 3.
 36 Chapter IV B. Financial and Economic Farm Model Analysis 4.4 Dairy farming is the dominant farming system in Estonia, and has the highest potential to develop into a profitable enterprise. The farm model analysis assesses the impact of the Project investments in farrn drainage rehabilitation and agricultural advisory services on farm income from dairy farms. In order to increase farm production and returns to capital and labor on a dairy farm, investments in drainage rehabilitation and agricultural advisory services have to be accompanied by other investments, typically in buildings (farm buildings, milking parlor), machinery (milking system), or livestock (milking cows). The farm model analysis therefore provides a financial and economic rate of return of the Project investments in drainage and advisory services in conjunction with assumed complementary privately financed investments in farm machinery, livestock and buildings. The investments would be self-financed or financed through commercial bank loans. 4.5 The impact of a combined investment in drainage rehabilitation, advisory services for promotion of improved pasture and livestock management supported through the Project, and the privately financed on-farm investments in farm buildings, livestock and machinery are evaluated using a model of a 25-ha private dairy farm. In the model calculation, the bulk of the investment costs (estimated at about EEK 90,000) can be attributed to buildings, machinery, and livestock (88% of the combined investment costs),2 whereas the corresponding costs to the farmer for drainage rehabilitation and advisory services are considerably lower (9% and 3% respectively of the combined investment costs).3 4.6 The Financial Rate of Return (FRR) of drainage rehabilitation, agricultural advisory services and the complementary privately financed investments in farm assets is estimated at 22% for the model farm. This FRR is based on the farmers' contribution to the investment requirements, the incremental benefits of these investments, and the projected incremental costs of agricultural production. 4.7 Farm Income and Farmers' Debt Servicing Capacitv. Assuming a fanner would take a loan (EEK 90,000; 10 year maturity; 2 year grace period; 4% real interest rate) to improve a 25 ha dairy farrn, a farmer could service the loan and after two years achieve an annual income that would be 40% higher than without the investment. Nine years after the initial investment, the model farm would provide a monthly income of EEK 1,130 per person4, which is comparable to the national average wage and nearly twice as high as the average farm wage. Model calculations for larger farms (50 ha and 100 ha) show that the profitability further increases with economies of scale. 4.8 Farm Model Economic Analysis. The economic analysis of the farm models uses import parity prices for cereals and fertilizers.4 All other input and output prices have been converted using a standard conversion factor of 1.0, equating financial and economic prices.5 The economic costs for 2 Farm credits are available from commercial banks refinanced through ARLCF. The ERR is lower than the FRR in the financial analysis reflecting the full investment costs for drainage rehabilitation and agricultural advisory services to the economy. Sensitivity Analysis for the Farm Model 4.10 Overall, the ERR of the farm models is not sensitive to significant changes in costs and benefits: benefits would need to fall by 24% or costs increase by 31% for the ERR to fall to 10% (i.e. with a net present value of zero). If the benefits are delayed by two years, the ERR would drop to 11%. In addition, a risk analysis6 for key assumptions, including: (a) inadequate rehabilitation and maintenance of the drainage systems beyond the project period; and (b) change of key agricultural output prices, has been prepared. The risk analysis shows that the ERR is sensitive to shortfalls in projected crop yield that might occur if drainage systems are not maintained. To ensure the projected yields are achieved in the Project area, the Project therefore carefully targets the investments to the high potential agricultural areas where farmers arguably have the highest incentives to maintain the infrastructure. Farmers' participation during rehabilitation and subsequent privatization of the drainage infrastructure would also promote a sense of ownership and responsibility for maintaining the drainage system. The crop and milk yield assumptions of the "with Project scenario" have been conservatively estimated and are not more than 10% higher than current average actual yields in Estonia. The risk of cost overruns is reduced by limiting rehabilitation expenditures to EEK 1,500 per hectare. It is also unlikely that crop or livestock prices would fall by more than 20%, due to the currently depressed output prices caused by the inefficient processing sector. C. However, as illustrated in the farm model analysis, many of the benefits of the components are interrelated and can not be analyzed, or achieved, in isolation. Land Reform 4.12 Benefits. The Project would support the development of a rural land market by accelerating the registration of rural land in the cadastre and title book. These measures would (a) facilitate the access of farmers to long-term credit because commercial banks would be more inclined to accept land with a secure, transferable and mortgageable title as collateral, and (b) increase the movement of agricultural land through sale or lease to efficient agricultural producers, thereby increasing agricultural production and incomes. 4.13 Cost Effectiveness Analysis. Land with a registered, secure, transfereable and mortgageable title could be used as collateral to obtain a long-term mortgage loan from a commercial bank. The benefit of land title registration could be assessed as the difference between the interest rate 6 See Annex 3.

A simple cost-effectiveness analysis shows that a reduction of the interest rate for a loan of EEK 100,000 (10 years maturity, no grace period, constant principal repayment) by 2% would be sufficient to cover the estimated costs of EEK 9,625 for land surveys and cadastre registration of an average 25 ha farm. The component would have substantial financial and economic benefits for the economy by supporting the development of mortgage banking. 4.14 Cost Recovery. The GOE plans to recover the costs for the land surveys from the property owners. For this purpose, the GOE is developing incentives to assist the owners in financing land surveys and registration in the cadastre and title book. The land surveys would be conducted by around 200 private surveying companies operating in Estonia. Farm Drainage Rehabilitation 4.15 The Project would finance rehabilitation of drainage systems on about 60,000 ha of the most productive drained farmland, covering less than 10% of the total drained farmland in the country. Well maintained and functioning drainage systems are a pre-requisite to increasing the efficiency of Estonian livestock farms. After fully rehabilitating the drainage system in the Project area, crop production would increase by about 11,000 tons of feed grain, 35,000 tons of hay, and 12,000 tons of potato annually. The incremental production of feed grain and hay, even though these crops could be valued with market prices, is only used as an intermediate good for dairy and livestock production and should not be valued separately'. The farm model analysis therefore provides the best approximation of the benefits of drainage rehabilitation. In addition, the organization of farmers in LWAs and the involvement of the farmers in the design of the drainage system could also result in new community services provided by these LWAs such as input supplies, machinery pools, marketing and possibly credit. Tlhe drainage rehabilitation investments would directly benefit small local contractors carrying out the civil works and also stimulate the development of other rural support services to agriculture in the rural areas. 4.16 Cost Recoverv. The GOE plans to privatize the ownership, operations, and maintenance of all farm drainage systems by handing over these systems to LWAs after completion of the drainage rehabilitation works. Each LWA must agree to contribute (in cash or in kind) 20% of the cost of the rehabilitation works, the remaining 80% would be covered by the GOE with budget and Project loan funds. In return, the GOE would, post-rehabilitation, no longer accept any further financial responsibility for these on-farm drainage systems. Each LWA would have full ownership of its area-specific drainage system and bear its full O&M costs. This will reduce the GOE's future investment costs in rehabilitating drainage systems and its recurrent expenditures for operation and maintenance of these systems. Research results confirm the significant and positive impact of extension in many countries. However, the benefits of extension during the transition period are extremely difficult to quantify due to the paucity of data and the lack of experience in similar situations. Evidence from an extension project in northern Estonia shows that minor improvements such as adequate maintenance of the milking equipment results in significant quality improvements. Quality improvements would substantially increase farm income because of the large difference in payment for low quality and high quality milk. 4.18 Public versus Private Advisory Services. The Project assists the establishment of a new advisory system in Estonia consisting of a public and a private extension service. The Private Advisory Services Development Fund requires only an initial investment, because the farmers are expected (in the medium-term) to fully pay for advice that directly benefits their farm operation. Over an eight year period the GOE's contribution to the private advisory service would be gradually phased out. In addition, the GOE, with Project support, would continue to provide advice to farmers who can not afford the private advisory services, but only with public domain technical information. The GOE would therefore reduce its active involvement in extension to a more strategic and supervisory role, thereby containing recurrent Government expenditures for extension. Food Quality Control and Veterinary Services 4.19 Benefits. The Project would improve state food quality and veterinary laboratories in order to protect domestic and foreign consumers, and increase the export potential of agricultural products. The Project investments are aimed at enhancing and monitoring the quality of food and livestock products in accordance with EU regulations. 4.20 Cost Effectiveness Analysis. Estonia does not fully use the quota for livestock exports to the EU at the favorable import tariff, which is 60% less than actual tariffs. If Estonian livestock products meet EU standards, the fulfillment of the quota would result in a tariff reduction of US $5 - 6 million over the next three years. The component investments (US $1.2 million) could therefore initiate production quality improvements at the farm level and in the food processing industries. However, private sector investments in production facilities at the farm level and at the agro-processing level would have to complement the Project investments to increase the quality of food and livestock products. 4.21 Public versus Private Investment and Cost Recoverv. The Project supports the initial phase of a broader program to improve Estonia's food quality at the production, processing and marketing level. Part of the future control functions would most likely be undertaken by private laboratories, but some of these functions would remain in Government hands. It is expected that the Veterinary Laboratory would charge for the tests to partially recover costs. Land Use Management 4.22 Benefits. This component is aimed at strengthening environmental controls in agriculture to minimize negative external effects of agricultural production on the environment. The MOE would actively participate in developing environmentally sustainable agriculture in Estonia. In addition, the MOE would receive Project support to develop and enforce environmental regulations and monitor the impact of the drainage rehabilitation investments on the environment.

 ANNEX 3 Page 1 of 37 ANNEX 3 ESTONIA AGRICULTURE PROJECT FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC ANALYSIS A. INTRODUCTION 1. In the financial and economic analysis, the Project benefits of the drainage rehabilitation component and the agricultural advisory component are going to be quantified in terms of the output of dairy and beef products. This analysis will be based on a dairy farm model of a typical 25 ha dairy farm in Estonia. Dairy farms of that size are now the dominating farm type producing the bulk of the agricultural output and have the largest potential to develop into profitable businesses. Drainage rehabilitation will increase the agricultural production of mainly forage crops and to a lesser extent cereals and potatoes. Rehabilitation and good maintenance of drainage systems are a key pre-requisite to improve the efficiency of livestock and crop production in Estonia. A well drained field has a growing season that is about a month longer than under wet conditions which then in turn allows higher crop yields or pasture improvements with nitrogen-fixing legumes. Increasing fodder production will in turn increase dairy and livestock production and lower production costs. Through the agricultural advisory services component, farmers will have access to advise on improved technologies or farm management methods through the support to the agricultural advisory service. 2. Scope of the Analysis. This annex consists of: (a) a financial and economic farm model analysis of the profitability of dairy and beef production; and (b) an analysis of economic benefits by Project component. C. FARM MODEL ANALYSIS 3. The farm model analysis assesses the impact of the Project investments in farm drainage rehabilitation and agricultural advisory services on farm income from dairy farms (the dominant farm type in Estonia). However, dairy farmers would in many cases have to invest in, for instance, expanding the herd size, or in new machinery for milking and fodder production to fully utilize the better drained fields and use the advice offered by the extension services. The farm model analysis therefore provides a financial and economic rate of return of the Project investments in drainage and advisory services in combination with assumed complementary privately financed investments in farm machinery, livestock and buildings. These Project benefits can only be evaluated accurately in conjunction with additional privately financed on-farm investments through the farm model and not separately by component. 4. Profitability of Crop Production. The profitability of the main value adding sub-sector, dairy production, depends on a certain yield level below which the production of fodder crops and cereals would not be profitable. The necessary crop yield level can generally only be obtained with adequate drainage. Most of the analyzed crops, except potatoes, are intermediate goods and used as livestock feed. Therefore the analysis of the FRR and the ERR focus on the impact of investments and increases of dairy and livestock production on model dairy farms in Estonia. Dairy Farm Models 6. Farm models have been developed to evaluate the profitability of dairy farms of varying sizes and different technology levels. The financial dairy farm models are developed to assess: (a) the current profitability of dairy farms; (b) the financial rate of return of on-farm investments in drainage rehabilitation, agricultural advisory services and complementary privately financed farm assets; (c) potential demand for loans, loan conditions, and debt service capacity of a model dairy farm, and (d) the economic rate of return of on-farm investments in drainage rehabilitation, agricultural advisory services and privately financed complementary farm assets. The complementary on-farm investments would be either self-financed or financed through loans obtained from commercial banks and are not provided under the Project. 7. Four different dairy farm types are analyzed: (a) A private farm of 25 ha representing present situation and practices, with 11 ha arable land, 3 ha grassland, 8 ha forest, and 3 ha of uncultivated land. The farm is oriented towards milk production with a herd of 13 cattle including 5 cows. Cropping pattern: 50% barley and other cereals, 44% pasture for hay and grazing, 1% beet and 5% potato. (Without Proiect Scenario). (b) A private farm of 25 ha as in (a) above, assuming changes in land use with crop rotation extended to nine years including three years of cultivation and six years of pasture, improved pasture management, improved feed conservation and an increase in herd size to 21 cattle including 10 cows. It is conservatively assumed that the investments result in a yield increase of 0.6 t/ha of barley, 4 tlha of potatoes, 2 tlha of pasture and an increase in production of 200 kg of milk per cow. Cropping pattern: 25% barley, 65% pasture hay, 5% legumes and 5% potato. (With Proiect Scenario). (c) A hypothetical 50 ha farm with the same management, land use, and cropping pattern as proposed for (b) above, with a herd of 45 cattle including 20 cows. (d) A hyRothetical 100 ha farm with the same management, land use, and cropping pattern as proposed for (b) above, with a herd of 88 cattle including 40 cows.

Environmental impact. The increase in herd size will lead to an increase in the amount of manure produced on the farrn which could increase non-point source pollution from agriculture if appropriate mitigation measures are not in place. It will be necessary for the expanding farms to invest in appropriate manure storage facilities and technology. In the model calculations, investment costs for appropriate manure storage have been included in estimating the costs of expanding the stables. It is further assumed that the farms will continue to use the existing technology for spreading manure. All new private investment involving the construction of cattle sheds for more than 10 cows have been classified by Estonian law as projects of local importance that have to undergo an environmental impact assessment before the investment is cleared by the County Environment Department. The Government thereby tries to assure that appropriate environmental mitigation measures are included. However, even after increasing herd size, the assumed animal density in the model farms will be lower than in many European countries. Farm Model Financial Analysis 14. The financial rate of return (FRR) for these investments on a 25 ha dairy farm is estimated at 22% and the net present value amounts to EEK 46,644. The FRR calculation is based on the following assumptions: (a) all costs are in constant end 1994 prices; (b) benefits and costs are calculated for 15 years; and (c) quantifiable net returns are from incremental dairy and meat production. Recent data published by MOA confirm the analysis and indicate that half of the private dairy farms in Estonia show a profit in 1994. Dairy farm profitability improved noticeably since 1993, partly due to comparable on- farm investments. Farmers' Debt Service Capacity 15. During the four year investment period, farm income before financing would drop to EEK 12,000 in the first year of the investment, and then increase to EEK 21,000 in the second year, EEK 35,000 in the third and stabilize at EEK 40,000 from the fourth year onwards. The decline in income in the first year is due to an internal build-up of the herd which prevents the sale of livestock during the first year.

Farm Model Economic Analysis 18. Commodity and lnvut Prices. Economic farmgate prices of cereals are calculated using averages of quoted CIF Rotterdam prices in 1995 of barley, rye and oats. For the purpose of economic analysis, an average import parity farmgate price of EEK 1,101 per ton for cereals is derived by averaging farmgate prices of barley, rye and oats. Considering that these cereals are used primarily as livestock feed grains, this average farmgate price for cereals is projected by correlating its price movement with the Bank's commodity price forecast of May 1995 for grain sorghum for years 1995 to 2005. The calculated economic farmgate prices show only minor variations from the actual financial farmgate prices observed. The average import parity farmgate prices of these feed grains are projected at EEK 1,055 per ton in 1995 up to the year 2000, and EEK 979 per ton in year 2005 and thereafter. Import parity prices have been calculated for fertilizers and cereals. The economic import parity farmgate prices for N, P, and K nutrients are derived from Urea, TSP and KCL prices respectively, based on the Bank's forecast of May 1995 for the years 1995 to 2005. Estonia is a net importer of these fertilizers. The farmgate import parity prices of these nutrients in 1995, expressed in constant 1994 terms, are estimated to be EEK 5.5/kg for N, EEK 4.5/kg for P, and EEK 3.0/kg for K. All other input and output prices have been converted using a standard conversion factor (SCF) of 1.0, equating financial and economic prices because of the absence of any trade restrictions. 19. The financial farngate price for milk is also used in the economic analysis. The farmgate milk price is not distorted because of Estonia's liberal and open trade and price policy. However, the costs of processing milk are high in international comparison because of the inefficient Estonian dairy processors. With the improvement of competition among milk processors, processing costs are expected to decrease in the future. Cost savings in processing could translate into higher farmgate milk prices and consequently increase the financial and economic rate of return of the described investments. 20. Methodology.
