The with Project model shows a positive Net Present Value (NPV) of 30,874 and an economic rate of return (ERR) of 16%. The ERR and NPV are lower than in the financial model reflecting the full investment costs for drainage rehabilitation and agricultural advisory services to the economy. Sensitivity Analysis 22. Overall, the ERR is robust to significant changes in costs and benefits: benefits would need to fall by 24% or costs increase by 31% for the ERR to fall to 10% (i.e. with a net present value of zero). If the benefits are delayed by two years, the ERR would drop to 11%. If simultaneously incremental costs increase by 20% and incremental benefits drop by 10%, the ERR would drop to 10%. In addition, a risk analysis for key assumptions, including (i) inadequate rehabilitation and maintenance of the drainage systems beyond the project period, (ii) shortfalls in projected yield or production increases, (iii) change of key agricultural output prices is presented below. 23. Inadequate rehabilitation and maintenance of the drainage system. Farmers would have to fully finance the rehabilitation of the drainage system after about nine years to increase the life of the drainage system to around 60 years. If farmers fail to rehabilitate the drainage system, and the incremental benefits would drop to zero after year 10, then the ERR would drop to 10%. Therefore the Project has emphasized that farmers are organized in Land and Water Associations (LWAs), and assume full responsibility for part of the investment costs, and all maintenance as well as future rehabilitation costs. In addition, the benefits of maintaining the drainage system are very high. 24. Shortfalls in projected crop yield. The model reacts sensitive to a shortfall in projected crop yields. The viability of the livestock farms is jeopardized when crop and pasture yields cannot be sustained at certain levels, a case when drainage systems are not rehabilitated and maintained. If crop yields are 10% lower than assumed, the ERR of the economic farm model would fall to 10%. If yields drop below the calculated level, the farm would then have to substitute the cheaper on-farm produced forage crops with more expensive cereals purchased on the markets. The sensitivity analysis underlines the importance of drainage rehabilitation being a pre-requisite to achieve and sustain the projected yields for crops and pasture. If maintenance of the drainage system is neglected over several years, yields may drop below the threshold yields resulting in cost of milk production that are higher than the current farmgate milk price. However, the estimates of incremental crop yields and incremental milk production are extremely conservative. For instance, barley yields have been projected to increase by only 0.6 t/ha to around 2.2 t/ha (with Project). The yields used in the "with Project" scenario are comparable to average Estonian barley yields that have fluctuated between 1.6 and 2.2 t/ha in the last two years whereas yields on well drained soils are often higher than 3 t/ha. 25. Change of key aericultural output prices. The model reacts less sensitive to changes of output prices. If the milk price drops by 20%, the ERR would fall to 9%. However, a drop of the milk price by 20% is unlikely, because the farmgate price is presently extremely low. Farmgate prices for milk are likely to increase, because the processing costs of Estonian dairy processing plants are expected to decline over the next years as the processors increase their productivity and reduce existing overcapacities.
 ANNEX 3 Page 7 of 37 C. ANALYSIS OF PROJECT BENEFITS BY COMPONENT 26. The economic analysis provides a discussion of the Project benefits for each component. However, as illustrated in the farm model analysis, many of the benefits of the component are interrelated and can not be analyzed, or achieved, in isolation. 27. Country and Agricultural Strategv. The Project follows the GOE's and the Bank's strategy to transform the rural sector, through supporting private agricultural and rural initiatives, into an economically viable and competitive market-based system. The agricultural strategy in the past and the near future aims at maintaining an open competitive agricultural sector based on private ownership of land, liberal agricultural trade policies, market determined agricultural prices, and limited budget transfers to the agricultural and rural sector. The liberal agricultural policy of Estonia to date can be described as exceptional within the former Soviet Union because prices and market distortions have been almost completely avoided. The recently completed Agricultural Sector Review for Estonia notes that low wages, low land costs, and the existing stock of skills and infrastructure provide Estonia with a competitive potential, primarily in dairy and related livestock production. The strategy is therefore aimed at increasing the efficiency and profitability of agriculture in Estonia and not primarily at increasing agricultural production or exports. Poverty and environmental issues related to the Project are discussed in separate sections in the SAR.4 28. Public versus Private Sector Investment. Following the outlined strategy, the Project selectively provides investments to improve existing key infrastructure in target areas (farm drainage rehabilitation), strengthen the public and support the development of a private advisory services, and enhance food quality control functions. The Project focuses on investments that initiate a gradual transfer of Govemment functions to the private sector (advisory services, drainage maintenance), or improve core Government functions (food quality control, public advisory services, environmental controls in agriculture). Land Reform 29. Benefits. The Project would support the development of a rural land market by accelerating the registration of rural land in the cadastre and title book. These measures would (i) facilitate the access of farmers to long-term credit because commercial banks would be more inclined to accept land with a secure, transferable and mortgageable title as collateral, and (ii) increase the movement of the production factor land through sale or lease to efficient agricultural producers, thereby increasing agricultural production and incomes. 30. Land with a secure and registered title could be used as an immoveable and mortgageable collateral to obtain a long-term loan from a commercial bank. Experience shows that long-term mortgage interest rates are generally lower than long-term interest rates for other loans not using "immoveable" land or buildings as collateral. At present, it is difficult to obtain long-term loans as the vast majority of all loans are for a maturity of less than 3 years. In addition, commercial banks in Estonia consider any land or building without a registration in the title book as moveable collateral and subsequently charge long- term interest rates of about 20 - 25%. It can be assumed that a mortgage banking system would provide farmers with access to long-term loan funds with lower than present interest rates. Mortgage banking is only in the initial stages of development but it is likely that it would develop rapidly, if land and buildings 4 For poverty analysis and for the environmental analysis compare Staff Appraisal Report, Chapter 2.

Artificially drained farmland has been an important feature of the Estonian agriculture, representing some 739,000 ha or 66% of the 1.12 million of amble land. Natural conditions for agriculture are far from optimal, primarily due to the short growing season and the generally poor soil fertility. The height of the growing season coincides with the period of highest rainfall. Although precipitation is fairly uniform between 570 and 720 mm/year, 65% of this rainfall occurs during the 5- 5 At present, there is no land market so that the land value is assumed at 1/6 of the average price of agricultural land in the US.
 ANNEX 3 Page 9 of 37 month period from May to September with peaks in July and August. Plant growth and harvesting on lands that have inadequate natural drainage are adversely affected by these conditions. The growing season on well drained fields is increased by about a month which results in earlier planting and subsequent higher yields. 34. The poor soil conditions and the short growing season are the major cause of the relatively low crop yields in Estonia. Rehabilitation and good maintenance of drainage systems are key to the increase the productivity of dairy farms. The farm improvements (reduction of livestock feed production costs and increase in herd outputs) described in the farm model analysis hinge on changes in land use, cropping patterns, improvement in pasture and livestock management, as well as introduction of improved grass and legume species in pastures. Higher yields depend on a grassland technology utilizing nitrogen fixing rhizobium activities of legumes. However, excessive soil moisture and poor soil aeration would inhibit the growth of the high yielding legumes and consequently lead to nitrogen deficient pastures which would naturally be overgrown with less productive grass and weeds. 35. Routine maintenance of farm drainage systems has been reduced substantially since 1989 and has eroded land productivity over time. Without regular maintenance and periodic rehabilitation, drainage efficiency and consequently crop yields will continue to decline. If crop yields cannot be sustained above the described yield threshold that guarantees positive returns, crop lands would be forced out of production. Moreover, if maintenance is deferred too long, these drainage systems can no longer be maintained or rehabilitated, and reconstruction would be prohibitive in costs and economically questionable. 36. Drainage Rehabilitation Investments. The Project therefore plans to rehabilitate about 60,000 ha of the most fertile drained agricultural land in about 60 separate locations. Areas for drainage rehabilitation works will be selected according to site selection criteria that include: (a) environmental screening; (b) soil fertility;6 (c) land use intensity; (d) condition of the drainage systems; (e) technical feasibility and designs; (f) investment cost ceiling; (g) status of land tenure; (h) farner's participation including various pre-conditions for local LWAs; and (i) location of markets. 37. Rehabilitation investments, including design and supervision, have been limited to expenditures of not more than EEK 1,500 per ha (in 1995 financial terms). This limitation ensures that rehabilitation investments are targeted to areas with low rehabilitation costs. In the future, routine maintenance and punctual rehabilitation will be required to sustain the expected benefits from drainage rehabilitation investments. While routine maintenance of the systems is required annually, punctual rehabilitation of the main and collector drains, and repair of the subsurface drain outlets should be carried out every nine to twelve years, in order to increase the life of the drainage system to 60 years. 38. Large areas of substandard drained agricultural land will continue to be forced out of production because it is no longer financially viable to maintain these systems. It can therefore be assumed that a small part of the reduction of agricultural lands can be attributed to the intensification of the production in the Project area. 40. Cost Recovery. GOE plans to privatize the ownership, operations, and maintenance of all farm drainage systems by handing over these systems to LWAs after completion of the drainage rehabilitation works. Responsibilities of LWAs are specified in the Amelioration Law (May 1994) and membership is compulsory for farmers in the drainage area. GOE has determined that each LWA must agree to contribute (in cash or in kind) 20% of the cost of the rehabilitation works, the remaining 80% would be covered by GOE with budget and Project loan funds. In return, GOE would, post-rehabilitation, no longer accept any further financial responsibility for these on-farm drainage systems. The cost sharing formula is a legal decision by GOE based on a rough analysis of what farmers' are prepared to contribute in labor towards the rehabilitation of the drainage system. Each LWA will have full ownership of its area-specific drainage system and bear full O&M costs. The LWAs are expected to finance a second round rehabilitation of the drainage systems after 9 - 12 years. Future GOE expenditures for drainage system maintenance would be reduced by more than the actual contribution to the rehabilitation costs. However, the ABs will continue to be responsible for operations and maintenance of rivers and main canals outside the drainage areas, as the main canals often serve other users such as industries and municipalities. Cost recovery options for maintenance of rivers and main canals are being considered, including the possibility of: (a) direct charges to landowners; and (b) transferring the financial responsibility of this maintenance to the respective municipalities which would then recover these costs through local taxes. 41. Crop Response to Drainage. Rehabilitation and good maintenance of drainage systems in the project area are expected to increase the growing season by one month, thereby contributing to incremental yields of 0.6 ton/ha for cereals (primarily barley, oats and rye), 0.9 ton/ha in hay equivalent for grassland, and 4 ton/ha for potato. These yield increments are considered conservative, and based on the actual difference between crop yields on lands with good drainage and yields on poorly drained lands. The cropping pattern in the project area is estimated to consist of 30% cereals, 65% pasture for silage and hay, and 5% potato on average. Most of the cereal production in Estonia is used for livestock feed and hay is a major input for dairy production. 42. Benefits. At full development, incremental production of feed grains in the project area of 60,000 ha (Base Case can be expected to reach 10,800 tons of feed grains, 35,100 tons of hay and 12,000 tons of potato per year. The incremental crop production, when translated into dry matter (about 31,600 tons) and nutritional values, is equivalent to the amount of feed required for producing 15 million liters of milk and 500 tons of beef (carcass weight). These equivalents in milk and meat production would represent 2% of the country's total milk production in 1993 of 750,000 tons and less than 1% of the beef production in 1993 of 115,000 tons (carcass weight). In addition, the organization of farmers in LWAs and the
 ANNEX 3 Page 11 of 37 involvement of the farmers in the design of the drainage system could also result in new community services provided by these LWAs, such as input supplies, machinery pools, marketing and possibly credit. The drainage rehabilitation investments would directly benefit small local contractors carrying out the civil works and would also stimulate the development of other rural support services to agriculture in the rural areas. 43. An Economic Rate of Return (ERR) for the farm drainage component has been calculated separately. The ERR for the farn drainage component is estimated at 23% and the net present value (NPV) of the projected net benefits amounts to EEK 26 million. The analysis is based on the economic costs for the rehabilitation and maintenance of the drainage system over 15 years and includes the system design, works supervision, and LWA establishment costs as well as a second rehabilitation after 9 - 12 years. Drainage system efficiency has been conservatively estimated at 90%. The incremental benefits are valued in terms of incremental production of hay, feed grains and potatoes. The benefits of rehabilitating the existing system are high due to substantial yield increases triggered by relatively minor costs for repairs and flushing of the system. 44. However, even though the incremental production of feed grain, hay and potatoes could be valued at market prices, the majority of the incremental production are only intermediate goods used for livestock production. As shown in the farm model analysis, the farm drainage rehabilitation investments are a prerequisite for complementary farm improvement investments aimed at increasing herd size, farm production, and farm income. The combined ERR of investments in drainage rehabilitation, agricultural advisory services and privately financed complementary investments is consequently lower than only looking at farm drainage rehabilitation separately. The farm model analysis therefore provides a realistic approximation of Project benefits for the drainage rehabilitation and agricultural advisory services components. Agricultural Advisory Services 45. Benefits. Extension plays a key role in the dissemination of information on new technologies, or improved organizational and management practices. Research results have confirmed that extension's impact on agriculture showed "a significant and positive external effect" in 33 analyzed cases. A calculation of net economic rates of return in eight studies shows highly positive results in eight cases, ranging from 14% to nearly 500% (Birkhaeuser, Evenson, and Feder, 1988). 46. Extension will likely have a substantial impact on the transformation of the Estonian farming sector to a market oriented production system. However, the impact of extension during the transition period is extremely difficult to quantify in isolation, due to the paucity of data, the lack of experience with similar situations, and in many cases the necessity to complement the advice with actual on-farm investments. Three sets of benefits can be expected: (a) benefits related to agricultural production; (b) environmental benefits; and (c) societal benefits. 47. Benefits related to (a) agricultural production in Estonia can be expected especially through increased production (higher yields), improved product quality (higher milk quality), and improved on- farm processing (improved storage of livestock feed). In addition, extension can help to reduce production costs through new technologies but also through promoting cooperation between farmers to jointly use farm machinery. (b) Environmental benefits can be expected through the promotion of improved and safe storage and application of manure, enhancement of soil fertility and reduction of agricultural run-off through drainage. Especially in the drainage rehabilitation area, extension service will play an important
 ANNEX 3 Page 12 of 37 role in providing information of reducing potential negative impacts of drainage rehabilitation. (c) Societal benefits can be expected through provision of advice on alternative employment opportunities in the rural areas, easing the transition out of agriculture, but also reducing the amount of out-migration from rural areas. Evidence from a donor-financed extension project suggests that already minor improvements of the maintenance of the milking equipment result in drastic quality improvements. These quality improvements result in substantial benefits for the farmers because of the large difference in payment for low quality and high quality milk. 48. Public versus private advisory services. The Project assists the establishment of a new advisory system in Estonia consisting of a public and a private extension service. This requires a redefinition of the Government's role in extension. The development of a public and private advisory service is based on a distinction between advice that has public good characteristics and advice that is a private good. The rationale is that the public sector will continue to pay for, but not necessarily implement, extension in some areas, but that the farmers will be expected to pay for advice that benefits them directly. In addition, some farmer's will have to leave agriculture, and information on alternative income provided by the public advisory service can speed up that process, thereby enhancing the profitability of the remaining farmers. 49. Cost recovery. The proposed support for Estonian advisory services is important, but limited, both in time and in scope. The Private Advisory Services Development Fund requires only an initial investment, because the farmers are expected to take over those programs over time. The fund will give non-transferable grants to farmers to pay for part of the advisory services of private advisors. Over an eight year period the Government contribution to the private advisory service will be gradually phased out. In addition, the Government will continue to fund a small public extension service, administered by the Farmer's Union, and equally supported under the Project. The public extension service will provide more technical advice of a general nature. The development of the private agricultural advisory services will reduce the number of county-level field staff (from 6-7 per county to about 3-4) employed by the Government. The Government will therefore reduce its active involvement in extension to a more strategic and supervisory role. This will over time substantially reduce GOE's recurrent expenditures

Benefits. The Project would improve one laboratory of the State Veterinary Department to improve health and quality standards in order to protect domestic and foreign consumers, and increase export potential of agricultural products. The Project investments are aimed at enhancing and monitoring the quality of food and livestock products in accordance with EU regulations. If Estonian livestock products meet EU standards, the tariffs for selected livestock exports to the EU would be reduced by 60% (US $5 - 6 million over the next three years). These investments, in the order of US $1.2 million, would initiate production quality improvements at the farm level and in the food processing industries. However, private sector investments in production facilities at the farm level and at the agro-processing level would have to complement the Project investments to increase the quality of food and livestock products. 51. Public versus Private Investment and Cost Recovery. The Project supports the initial phase of a broader program to improve Estonia's food quality at the production, processing and marketing level. Part of the future control functions would be undertaken by private laboratories, but some of these functions would remain in Government hands.  ANNEX 4 Page 1 of 8 ANNEX 4 ESTONIA AGRICULTURE PROJECT ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW INTRODUCTION 1. Introduction. The proposed loan to the agricultural sector in Estonia has been developed to support economic transformation in rural areas. The loan package includes investments in land reform, farm drainage rehabilitation, land management studies, agricultural extension and food quality control laboratory. The Staff Appraisal Report (SAR) describes the proposed project framework, objectives, and component in detail while this annex focuses specifically on the environmental review process, mitigation and monitoring proposed for the project. A draft overview of environmental issues in Estonia is being prepared by the World Bank. In addition, the World Bank is preparing a "Biodiversity Strategy" which is financed through the Global Environmental Facility (GEF). ENVIRONMENTAL FRAMEWORK 2. Estonian Environmental Strategy. The cornerstone of Estonian environmental policy is sustainable development which considers the basic needs of the present and the future. Estonian environmental policy encourages a shift from previous production based actions to use of an ecologically based systemic approach to balance human needs with ecologically sustainable practices (Keskkond, 1993). The proposed Agriculture Project must be consistent with Estonian enviromnental goals by including concerns for the sustainable use of natural resources into plans for development and restructuring of the rural sector. This environmental review is a mechanism to assure that all relevant environmental concerns are addressed in the project plans, recommended mitigation, and the project monitoring program. 3. Regulatory Framework. Estonia Governmental Regulation No. 314, adopted in November 1992, describes procedures for Environmental Impact Assessment. Under the Estonian system, a project may be categorized as a project of State Importance, Regional Importance, or one which does not require an environmental assessment. Projects of state importance are typically larger in scale with potential impacts crossing county borders. Environmental assessments and reviews for state importance projects are conducted by the Ministry of the Environment. Projects of regional importance are typically smaller in size, located within the boundaries of a particular county, and environmental reviews and assessments are conducted at the County Environmental Departments. 4. Environmental review is required for all World Bank loans and credits as described in the World Bank Operational Directive 4.01, "Environmental Assessment." The purpose of the environmental review process is: "to ensure that development options under consideration are environmentally sound and sustainable and that any environmental consequences are recognized early and taken into consideration in project design."
 Estonia Agriculture Project: Environmental Review ANNEX 4 Page 2 of 8 5. The World Bank's environmental review procedures require the classification of projects into one of three categories (A,B,C) that consider the nature, magnitude, and sensitivity of environmental issues. Classification of a project is achieved through a screening process beginning at initial project identification and continuing through project appraisal as more information becomes available. A detailed Environmental Assessment (EA) document is normally required for category A projects that have potentially diverse and significant environmental impacts. Category B projects undergo a more limited environmental analysis since the potential environmental impacts are less severe. A project would be classified into category C during environmental screening if it had minimal to no environmental impacts. 6. Environmental Screening. Table 1 (to this annex) presents results of environmental screening by the Estonian Ministry of the Environment and the World Bank for the Project. World Bank guidelines recommend that the most stringent classification of any individual project component shall determine the overall project classification. Both World Bank and Estonian environmental review procedures were used to classify project components. The Farm Drainage Rehabilitation project component has been classified as category B under the World Bank guidelines. This component will require further screening for specific investments during the course of project implementation. Therefore, the environmental review focuses on the proposed screening and impact analysis process. 7. Environmental screening under the Estonian Environmental Impact guidelines classifies the Wetlands Management Strategy Plan as of state importance. This study is considered strategically important to Estonia and thus would benefit from public participation and full consideration of environmental issues early in the planning process. All other project components were classified under World Bank guidelines as category C, or under Estonian guidelines as not requiring an environmental assessment or review. It is recognized, however that actions taken based on technical assistance, studies, and strategies may have environmental impacts and quite often involve issues with a direct influence on the environment. The World Bank encourages and supports the Estonian decision to conduct environmental assessments on technical assistance, studies, and strategies of regional or state importance. Environmental reviews performed early in the process reduce the need for more detailed reviews further downstream and provide a much better framework for future planning decisions. 8. Consultation Process. The Project is being designed in collaboration with the Ministry of Environment which is one of the implementing agencies besides the Ministry of Agriculture and the Ministry of Finance. The Environmental Assessment Division of the Ministry of the Environment is responsible for oversight of the preparation of the environmental review activities of the Project. The Water Department of the Ministry of Environment is responsible for all environmental regulations and screening procedures regarding the farm drainage rehabilitation component. A number of non- governmental organizations have been consulted during the Project preparation process, especially regarding the farm drainage rehabilitation and the rural finance component. Mission members met with the Stockholm Environment Institute - Tallinn which has been contracted to prepare supplementary information and a training course on the environmental screening criteria for commercial banks using the World Bank Refinancing Facility. Representatives of the Estonia Fund for Nature (Westonia Project) have provided written comments during preparation which are included in the background working papers. In addition, mission members met with the Estonian Farmers Union, staff of the University of Tartu, and the Estonia Academy of Sciences, Institute of Technology. Representatives of the Matsalu State Nature Reserve have been consulted concerning the design of the environmental screening criteria for farm drainage rehabilitation in the catchment area of the Reserve, given the ecological importance of this area.
 Estonia Agriculture Project: Environmental Review ANNEX 4 Page 3 of 8 FARM DRAINAGE REHABILITATION 9. Farm drainage rehabilitation investments. Investments are proposed to rehabilitate and maintain selected drainage channels and supporting infrastructure in critical farming areas to prevent permanent damage to existing farm drainage systems. Maintenance of fann drainage infrastructure has been neglected during the previous years due to a lack of funding resulting in clogging of subsurface pipes and reduction in channel conveyance capacity. Investments under this loan are very limited, and will be selected using evaluation criteria to maximize improvements to the most productive agricultural lands and to minimize environmental damage. Land amelioration (new drainage) will be limited to rehabilitation of existing works and will not involve investments in new drainage schemes, nor include polders where submerged lands are now drained for agricultural purposes, or support the drainage of "wet forests ". 10. Proposed drainage investments during the investment period include 200 kilometers (km) of rehabilitation and 1250 km of maintenance of the main drainage channels; 1500 km of rehabilitation and 3400 km of maintenance of collector (secondary) drainage channels; and pipe cleanout (flushing sediment) at approximately 15,000 outlets in both main and collector drainage channels during rehabilitation. Drainage investments are estimated to support approximately 60,000 hectares of land. Environmental reviews will be conducted, if necessary, following Estonian and World Bank procedures. However, drainage investment site selection with use agreed screening criteria to minimize potential damage to the environment. Consultations have been undertaken in preparation of the proposed Project with representatives of the Matsalu State Nature Reserve to review their views on potential activities in this catchment area. 11. Environmental screening and monitoring. The Ministry of Enviromnent has devised a two step approach to ensure that the drainage rehabilitation investments will be undertaken in a way to ensure minimal potential damage to the environment and public concerns are'adequately addressed. The environmental screening and monitoring procedures are based on the Water Law (adopted May 1994) that regulates water protection matters, and the Law on Environmental Protection of Shores and Banks (adopted in 1995) that regulates environmental protective measures for natural streams and drains. The two step environmental screening approach consists of: (a) environmental screening during site selection and (b) environmental guidelines for the design of drainage rehabilitation schemes: 12. Environmental screening during the site selection phase Screening criteria will be used to exclude certain areas as potential project sites to minimize environmental damage. These have been drafted by MOE, Dept. of Environmental Impact Assessment. This includes: (a) work will not be performed in areas where fish and wildlife habitat is protected by Estonian environmental laws or rules; (b) wetlands and estuaries with important wildlife or fishery values will be avoided; (c) important native grasslands or forest lands of special significance will be avoided; (d) national forest lands will be avoided until a forestry strategy is completed; and (e) polders will be avoided until special site-specific environmental studies have been prepared. Each site proposed by the Amelioration Units will be assessed by a local environmental consultant (financed through project funds) who prepares an EIA report. This report will be reviewed by the County Environment Department.
 Estonia Agriculture Project: Environmental Review ANNEX 4 Page 4 of 8 - Water quality of the proposed drainage sites will be analyzed' to determine limits for nutrient effluent in the drain water after rehabilitation. - The local Anelioration Bureau and the County Enviromnent Department would then inform the public of the proposed project rehabilitation site and give the public (incl. NGO's) a possibility to comment on the suitability of the proposed site for drainage rehabilitation . - The County Environment Department then decides if the site is acceptable for drainage rehabilitation and makes a recommendation to MOE and MOA. - In the case of highly sensitive areas (for example the catchment area of the Matsalu State Nature Reserve) a final decision will be taken by MOE. 13. Environmental screening during the design phase. - Environmental Guidelines for design of drainage rehabilitation works will be issued by MOE. They cover: size of drainage units, regulations for dredging and straightening of inlets, use of buffer areas or water protection belts, construction of sedimentation ponds, and, in certain cases, long-term use of agricultural inputs. - 'County Environment Departments will receive design plans for drainage rehabilitation for approval and make recommendations on necessary mitigation measures. In critical cases final r ecommendations will be issued by MOE. 14. Different and stricter guidelines are proposed for all areas that are under enviromnental protection, which includes ecologically sensitive areas like the catchment area of the Matsalu State Nature Reserve. The screening criteria listed above are intentionally stringent to minimize investments in project sites that require detailed environmental reviews during the early project stages. 15. Maintenance of open drain channels will be carried out using techniques to minimize environmental damages such as: (i) limiting excavation to design cross-sectional lines when channel cleanouts are carried out; (ii) having equipment work from one side of the channel whenever possible; (iii) consideration of sediment control by minimizing damage to vegetation on channel side slopes when possible, and (iv) installing sediment traps when needed. 16. Major Findings. Potential environmental impacts from drainage rehabilitation and maintenance include increased sedimentation, loss of critical wetland areas, groundwater table impacts, loss of wildlife habitats, and downstream impacts to sensitive or protected environments. Mitigation measures to minimize or prevent these impacts are available and shall be included in the project design. Some areas of Estonia have large beaver populations that have historically caused damage to drainage infrastructure. Mitigation against beaver damage may be required for proposed investments near large beaver populations. Laboratory equipment will be purchased by MOE using Project funds.
 Estonia Agriculture Project: Environmental Review ANNEX 4 Page 5 of 8 17. Proposed Mitigation Plan. The outlined environmental criteria for drainage rehabilitation will ensure minimal potential damage to the environment and apply to all future drainage rehabilitation works (above a certain minimum size). e.g., not only to the project financed rehabilitation works. MOE plans to issue the environmental guidelines and the consultation process as a Ministerial Decree or a Governmental Decree. Mitigation measures included in the overall project design are the use of initial environmental screening criteria for investment site selection; and recommended environmentally sensitive practices for implementation of drainage improvements. Site specific mitigation measures for investments will be approved by the Ministry of the Environment county or state environmental impact assessment staff on a case-by-case basis. Proposed technical assistance for environmental studies and drainage research and curriculum revisions will provide a complementary infornation source for the development and recommendation of mitigation measures. Research and studies would emphasize adaptive and applied field methods to reduce maintenance costs, improve the sustainability of drainage systems, and promote environmental protection. 18. All proposed drainage investments shall be consistent with local land use management plans. The Estonian Act on Land Cadastre passed in October, 1994 and effective January, 1995 describes procedures for updating and establishing land use management plans. Revised land use management plans should consider the importance of the environment, economic changes in the municipality, and desirable social and economic projections 19. Environmental Monitoring Plan. World Bank monitoring of the drainage investments would be performed during regularly scheduled supervision missions. The Ministry of the Environment would screen each proposed drainage investment plan receiving funding under this loan for environmental impact assessment requirements. The Project Implementation Unit (PIU) would maintain records of each letter from the Ministry of the Environment granting clearance of site specific investments. Proposed investments that require an environmental assessment under the Estonian guidelines would be reviewed by World Bank environmental staff for consistency and compliance with World Bank procedures. ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS 20. Environmental Benefits. Environmental benefits will be provided by several technical assistance project components. A reorientation of drainage research and educational curriculum will emphasize adaptive and field methods to reduce maintenance costs, improve sustainability of drainage systems, and promote environmental protection. Environmental studies targeted at drainage investments during the loan period and the future will assure that investments are made in an environmentally sensitive manner. The agricultural training and field extension services provide an opportunity to establish more sustainable farming practices than have been used in the past. Extension services would also address environmental concerns related to farming practices through input provided by local county environmental staff. 21. The Wetlands Management Strategy Plan will provide a framework for future management of these natural resources in a sustainable manner. The proposed Wetlands Management Strategy Plan would complement the ongoing "Wetstonia Project" and develop a system for valuing wetlands considering physical, hydrological, and biological criteria, as well as conservation and development goals. The strategy will provide guidelines and a framework for rehabilitation of peat-mined areas and wetland restoration projects.
 Estonia Agriculture Project: Environmental Review ANNEX 4 Page 6 of 8 CONCLUSION 22. Conclusion. No major significant adverse environmental impacts are anticipated from this project. The component that was classified as category B and will require additional environmental screening for specific investments as they are proposed during the investment period. Therefore, this environrental review has focused on the procedures in place to ensure that investments are environmentally sound and sustainable. The project will be regularly monitored for environmental issues by the Ministry of Environment. The World Bank will be kept informed by MOE of any drainage investments that require environmental assessments and will review environmental documentation by the PIU on supervision missions.

(1) Assist the Ministries in drawing up individual job descriptions for administrative staff assigned for handling procurement related matters, identify training requirements for the staff, and perform the necessary training through workshops and on-the-job applications. As appropriate, provide relevant recommendations to the Ministries in order to ensure that project procurement activities and their management are undertaken in an efficient, cost effective and timely manner. C. Timing The PIU will recruit a Procurement Specialist (national expert) for a 5-year period as part of the PIU staff. In addition, the PIU will require professional services from a Procurement Consultant (intematonal) for a duration of about 15 person-months over
 ANNEX 5 Page 8 of 13 a period of 3 years (1996-1998) of the project. Depending on the readiness of the PIU, the Consultant's services may be mobilized in late 1995 or early of 1996, to speed up procurement preparation. It is expected that all procurement activities would be fully undertaken and managed by the PIU and national staff of the Ministries, without further international consultant's assistance during the last three years of the project. D. Qualficatons: The PIU Procurement Specialist (national expert) must have a university degree in either administration, business, economics, engineering, management or related technical fields, with at least 12 months of work experience in commerce, management and administration. Preference would be given to persons possessing experience in procurement of goods, works and services internationally and in Estonia. The Procurement Consultant (international) must possess a university degree and have at least 5 years of experience in the management and administration of procurement of goods, works and services in the context of World Bank funded projects. The Consultant must be familiar with procurement and commercial practices acceptable to the World Bank, and conversant with the Bank's guidelines on procurement. Professional Services: Accounting A. Objectives While the PIU recruits a Project Accountant as part of its staff, the project will in addition require professional services from international and local consultants to: (a) set up the project accounts and their procedures in accordance with the requirements of the project; and (b) work with the Project Accountant in the PIU to train relevant national project staff of the implementing agencies in MOA and MOE, on the project accounts, including procedures for internal auditing. B. Tasks The scope of the professional services includes the following: (a) Based on the requirements of the project, including those outlined in the Bank's Guidelines for Financial Reporting and Auditing of Projects Financed by the World Bank (March. 1982), work with the Project Accountant (PIU) and establish a system for project accounts to cover the accounting needs of all Bank-financed project components. The project accounting system will take the following into consideration: (1) Development of a chart of accounts, general ledgers and sub-ledgers, as
 ANNEX 5 Page 9 of 13 appropriate and consistent with project budgetary and expenditure accounts for use in the PIU and by the implementing line agencies. (2) Documentation and requirements related to World Bank loan disbursements, taking into account the necessary records of transactions to be kept in support of disbursement applications made on the basis of Statement of Expenditures (SOEs) and other disbursement procedures. (3) Cross-references and harmonization with contract management, files/records under project administration. (4) Reconciliation of accounts and supporting documentation related to eligible expenditures with respect to the Special Account of the project, and the necessary requirements to support replenishment applications. (5) Progress and financial reporting requirements as agreed between the Government of Estonia and the World Bank. (6) Relevant covenants of the loan agreement, particularly those relating to procurement, disbursement, accounts and audit. (b) Based on the project accounting system, training sessions will be designed and delivered to familiarize the accounting and administration staff of the project with the system. On-the-job training and assistance continue until such time that the accounting operations of the project run satisfactorily. Loan disbursement procedures of the World Bank will be incorporated into the thuining sessions. Mechanisms for internal auditing will be incorporated into the training program. (c) Integration of project accounts and budget accounting within each of the implementing agencies responsible for project components. Reporting to the PIU Project Manager, the primary responsibility of the Project Accountant will include the following: (1) Reporting to the Project Manager of the PIU, perform day-to-day accounting tasks related to all aspects of the project accounts. (2) Ensure that all line implementing agencies under the Project conform with the accounting and financial reporting requirements of the project. (3) Work with the Procurement Specialist of the PIU, including the Procurement Consultant, to harmonize accounting requirements with both procurement and loan disbursement requirements.
 ANNEX 5 Page 10 of 13 (4) Prepare (a) loan disbursement applications; (b) monthly reconciliation of accounts of all project components and their expenditures; (c) replenishment application for the Special Account; and (d) other financial documentation as necessary. Assist and work with the line implementing agencies in the preparation of project component budgets. Perform financial monitoring of project activities, and present financial analysis as required of the PIU. C. Timing Part-dime professional services from international and local consultants will be required for a period of about 6 person-months spread over the first two years of the project. It is expected that the project staff in the Project Implementation Unit and line implementing agencies will be able to handle the operations of the project accounts without further assistance, commencing from the third year of the project. The Project Accountant's position is for a duration of 5 years. Professional Services: Monitoring and Evaluation Specialist A. Tasks As part of the Project Implementation Unit and reporting to the PIU Project Manager, the Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) Specialist is required to: (a) Work with the Amelioration Unit and Amelioration Bureaux, and assist them in site selection of drainage systems for rehabilitation, by reviewing the economic selection criteria used for specific sites. Several factors to be considered include the following: the average cost of rehabilitation, including design, civil works and supervision. Severely damaged systems and areas, requiring more than rehabilitation, must be excluded as reconstruction costs are prohibitive and economically questionable. The profitability of farm operations on the proposed sites, and the potential gains that can be attributed to drainage improvement. This potential may include among other things: (i) changes to cropping patterns and intensity; (ii) potential introduction of new technology (such as grassland with legumes); (iii) the possibility of early planting and delaying harvest time - lengthening growing season by improving drainage conditions during critical periods; and (iv) crop yield improvement and expected yields that can surpass profitable yield thresholds.
 ANNEX 5 Page 11 of 13 (b) Work with the Land Board and the Amelioration Unit, and ensure that priorities for cadastral land surveys and registration include the proposed drainage sites, and that timing for these surveys is suitably planned to clarify land tenure issues in the context of LWA development. (c) Work closely with the Amelioration Unit and the Task Force of the Agriculture Advisory Services, and ensure that LWAs of the proposed drainage sites receive adequate attention in the targeting of extension and advisory services. Demand for advisory services among these LWAs will be assessed and responded to. (d) Together with the respective implementing agencies, based on the Project Implementation Plans develop a monitoring and evaluation (M&E) system for each project component, incorporating indicators for measuring project inputs, outputs, impacts (micro and macro) and the means for verifying and measuring these indicators. (e) Periodically, monitor and evaluate progress of implementation of all project components, provide concise notes on possible measures for overcoming major issues that constrain project implementation, for the attention of the PIU Manager and the respective implementing agencies. (f) Identify bottlenecks and systemic problems in implementation, and review these conditions jointly with the relevant agencies to come up with measures and options for solving these problems. Alert the PIU Project Manager of major problems that require the attention of the Inter-Ministerial Project Steering Committee and/or the Joint Project Directors at MOA and MOE. (g) Assist all implementing agencies, on financial, cost and economic analyses related to their project components; and when appropriate also involve the Procurement Specialist and the Project Accountant of the PIU in the context of these analyses. (h) Develop rural income indicators, assess on and off-farm employment in project target areas, and perform pre and post investment M&E on a sample basis. (i) Carry out field monitoring trips on a regular basis, in association with the implementing agencies, and test out these M&E systems for further refinement as necessary. Ensure that the M&E systems provide immediate feedback to allow corrective measures to be introduced as early as possible. (j) Liaise with MOA and MOE policy units and develop environmental economic impact assessment indicators for project target areas.
 ANNEX 5 Page 12 of 13 (k) Follow up on the development of land policy concerning land reform and disposal of state lands, and monitor progress on land restitution in the project areas, including cadastral registration and land titling. (1) Perform other tasks on monitoring and evaluation as assigned by the PIU Project Manager. B. Timing and Qualifications The position is for a duration of 5 years in the PIU. The selected person must possess a university degree in either economics, agricultural economics, business management, agriculture, engineering, or related fields, with at least 12 months experience in financial and economic evaluation of investment programs. Experience in monitoring and evaluation of projects is highly desirable. Professional Services: Project Management A. Objectives The objective of this consultancy is to train national project staff assigned by the Ministries of Agriculture and Environment, on relevant aspects of project management and administration, including monitoring and evaluation. B. Tasks The tasks of the Project Management consultant include the following: (a) Conduct a rapid training needs assessment, based on the management and administration requirements of the project and its components. (b) Design an appropriate training package, incorporating fundamental principles of project management including topics to cover the following: (i) application of management principles to plan, organize, staff, control and direct resources (including budgeting); (ii) techniques commonly used in operational planning, including the application of critical path analysis and resource driven scheduling; (iii) the use of computer software applications for project planning, management, and administration, including spreadsheet applications;
 Page 13 of 13 (iv) planning of actions and tasks for achieving project objectives, and organizing the necessary resources for carrying out the plan; (v) communications, including techniques for effective presentations, meetings and negotiations; (vi) task management, including: division of tasks, organization of work arrangements, roles and functions of work-groups, special task forces, responsibility matrix, reporting channels, work delegation, and other management functions and tools; (vii) monitoring and evaluation of physical progress of project implementation, including use of indicators for measuring inputs, outputs, impacts, progress milestones, and means for verifying these indicators; (viii) project administration requirements, including: files and records management, contract management (procurement aspects covered under a separate terms of reference), project accounts (a separate terms of reference to set up and maintain these accounts), logistical and secretarial tasks; (ix) other topics, as assessed to be necessary during training needs assessment, to ensure the delivery of a comprehensive project management training. (c) Train staff of the Project Implementation Unit (PIU), and project staff of the implementing agencies, through workshops and on-the-job applications. C. Timing Consultant's services will be required for a period of about 3 person-months, and the training program is to be conducted in three stages: (a) training needs assessment; (b) design of training sessions; and (c) delivery of training. A combination of international and local consultants are required for the delivery of the training program. This training program will be delivered as soon as possible after (a) all PIU staff have been hired; and (b) accounts and procurement systems are in place.

 Estonia Agriculture Project Project Implementation Plan Land Reform Component I. The Project A. Component Objectives 1. The broad objective of the land reform component of the project is to assist Estonia in the development of the land market, which would facilitate: (a) the land reform (restitution and privatization of the land); (b) the use of land as collateral to obtain long tern credit, and subsequent farm restructuring; and (c) exit and entry into farming. The establishment of such a market requires developing the legal framework, as well as the technical and institutional capacity. The immediate and main objective of the project component is to speed up land survey and land registration in the land cadastre. B. Component Scope 2. Land Reform. The total area of agricultural and forest lands to be eventually privatized is estimated at 2.3 million hectares (including natural grasslands, arable land, orchards and forests). The reform of land ownership, farm organization and property rights is a central element of Estonia's economic reform. The actual process of formal transfer of ownership to the newly established private farms has been slower than desirable. Despite the importance attached by GOE to land reform and privatization, only 13% of this area has been divested to private control to date (including restituted land and land under the Farn Law Act of 1989). The slow progress of land reform can be attributed variously to the difficulties in the development of the legal frmework, insufficient institutional arrangements, and limited financial resources to complete the land surveys. The approach chosen for the land reform - physical restitution based on pre-1940 boundaries - seems to be the most significant factor in slowing down land privatization, and creating uncertainties as to the rights of the farmers. Even if restitution were proceed faster, it is unclear that it would improve land use and expedite the development of an active land market. Many land owners have chosen alternative lands or non-land compensation in place of accepting their "ancestral lands." Consequently, a significant amount of the arable and forest lands remains under state ownership after the end of the first stage of land reform. 3. Up to December 1995, 23,529 units (approx. 223,000 ha) have been registered in the cadastre and 11,000 parcels (approx. 180,000 ha) in the title book. Estimated registration in 1995 was 15,000 units (approx. 130,000 ha). The National Land Board (NLB) plans to register over 1,500 cadastral units (13,000 ha) per month in 1996. 4. The implementation of land reform in Estonia requires well-defined prerequisites and priorities, as well as better sequencing of reform elements, so that a well-functioning land market can emerge. The most important part of the land reform is to continue, and finalize the restitution of the properties. An important task for GOE is to work out a state land disposal policy for state- owned lands in rural areas. The project also aims to accelerate the reform process on areas where it has been slow.
 PIP I Page 2 of 9 5. SimRlifving cadastral and title book registration. Titling is not an end in itself, but a means to achieve security of tenure, and to provide information to facilitate land transactions through an accurate and up-to-date registration system. Estonia adopted a land registration system that is close to the German Real Property System and requires registration based on exact land survey. The titling procedure was already simplified by the "Law of Amending the Legal Acts Relating to the Implementation Law of Real Property Law", (August 12, 1994). However, the Title Book Offices still need three months to register the title, which prolongs the procedure. 6. The Government is working on simplifying regulations and devising appropriate measures to limit the cost and time spent per unit restituted or privatized. The Governmental Decree "The order for restitution of the properties on the base of existing maps" was passed in early 1995. This order allows restitution of lands to the previous owners without completing an exact land survey. The property borders would be registered based on existing maps prepared during the Soviet era. However, only 20% of all properties could be registered this way. Another option being explored would include the issuance of a "provisional" title with regard to the estimated boundaries. Boundaries would only be demarcated in the field and simply indicated to owners. Boundaries would also be registered on the cadastral maps. Further clarification of boundaries can be done later, if deemed necessary by appropriate parties, prior to market transactions (buyers, sellers, banks, etc.). Despite the above options, experience in East Gernany shows that transitional measures cannot fully compensate for exact surveys, and that there is no alternative to carrying out land surveys. Regardless of the legal framework, owners need to know what precisely they own, and where their borders are, especially when it comes to land transactions and cultivation. 7. Physical restitution versus voucher compensation. The vouchers will be replaced with special privatization banking accounts. It is possible to use the privatization bank accounts to pay for privatized lands and other properties. The compensation for lands and other properties is deposited in a privatization bank account, and can be used for privatization of apartments, lands, shares of companies, etc. In some rural areas, it seems likely that owners would more readily accept compensation than restitution. In Tallinn, for instance, almost every property will be restituted, but many owners opt for compensation for their agricultural lands in rural areas. However the compensation value for rural lands is small. Owners are not willing to opt for compensation immediately, and are postponing their decisions, although every owner was supposed to have decided by April 1995 whether to opt for restitution or compensation. The new Govermment has decided to compensate only the lands that could not be restituted. 8. Reorganization of Est-survey. In a market economy, there is little need for parcel surveying to be carried out by a public agency. To expedite parcel surveys, Est-survey, the state- owned land survey company, which has already lost more than half of it's surveyors to the private sector, needs to be privatized. Reorganization of the National Land Board (NLB) has started by re-integrating the Department of the Cadastre of Est-survey into NLB. The cadastral Center of NLB was established. The County Land Cadastre Offices have been established in ten of the counties and the rest (five) will be established before the end of May, 1996. A special Decree passed by the Government (Decree 9, January, 1995) regulates the re-organization of the National Land Board. The Decree specifies that: (a) The NLB would be an effective organization responsible for Land Cadastre, Geodesy and Mapping;
 PIP I Page 3 of 9 (b) The activities of NLB would be coordinated with other involved institutions; and (c) The NLB should not compete with the private sector on an equal basis for specific land survey activities. 9. The Governmental Decree further stipulates that: (a) The Department of the Cadastre of Est-survey, the Department of Informatics, and the Archive shall be re-integrated into NLB. (b) The Mapping Center shall be re-integrated into the NLB. (c) The County Est-Survey Offices will be privatized or terninated. 10 Privatization of the county land survey offices was planned for the beginning of 1996. NLB hopes that the tender for privatizing the first five County Offices of Est-survey can be published by May, 1996 and that the bidding process can take place before June, 1996. 11. Role of private sector At the present moment, there are 125 licensed private surveying companies, and 48 individual surveyors in Estonia that are involved in land surveying, which is a necessary part of the process of restitution, replacement, selling and purchase of land, as well as of the contractual use of land. In addition, 138 licenses for geodetic and cartographic work have been given out. A study has shown that approximately 95% of the companies are now actively operating. There are still an additional 39 private companies and surveyors that have applied for a license. In the near future, a new status of surveyor will be given out to some of the license owners. In addition to the surveying work, the owner of the new license could also perform juridical operations regarding cadastre works. According to estimations, the above- mentioned companies would continue the work in the future, but their activities would be supervised and they would be provided with up-to-date geodetic network information and existing map information in order to guarantee a coordinated functioning of the whole cadastral system. This task would be performed by the NLB. 12. Prioritization and sequencing of survey works and cadastre registration. Even after all the above measures are taken, the costs of titling, and the time it takes, are likely to be substantial. Systematic titling should be sequenced and prioritized. The following criteria to prioritize the survey work location, in order of importance are: (a) Drainage rehabilitation sites: The project supports the rehabilitation of drainage systems and these lands should be surveyed as a first priority. A large number of the properties surveyed under this project can be selected on the basis of drainage rehabilitation areas. (b) Regional Policy Sites: These are areas where land reform has been slow in the past and where demand for restitution is limited, but develop of local infrastructure and farming is important.
 PIP 1 Page 4 of 9 (c) Higher potential market value: These are areas with desirable land use/quality attributes, or location attributes, such as better soil quality, better access to the urban markets, etc. (d) Lower potential cost for adjudication: These are areas where potential owners are easily identifiable and whose claims are least likely to be contested by others in the process of titling. Land covered by the present farming law, in which the private farmers have perpetual use rights but no rights to sell or mortgage land, can fit into this criteria. 13. Adiustment in land confiauration and easements: The restructuring of large enterprise farms offers the opportunity for adjusting the shapes and sizes of the subdivided parcels within these farms. This is especially a problem where restituted owners have fragmented pieces of land within a large farm, or where such pieces have no access to roads or services. ONGOING AND REQUESTED PROJECTS 14. Under separate arrangements, donor-funded parallel projects provide technical assistance and training for strengthening the institutional and technical capacities of the NLB and related agencies. (a) Land Registry Management Advice (96-98) will be carried out by SwedSurvey and financed by Sweden as part of larger program which has been agreed in principle for 1996. Continuation of this sub-component is agreed with SwedSurvey for longer term. (b) Land Assessment Methodology Development (95-96) has been agreed with the Finnish Government and the project is running. The land assessment methodology so far has been created in close cooperation with Finnish experts and the changes into the system will be worked out together. (c) Land and Real Estate Legal Advice (96-98) has been intensively investigated and two possible donors have been identified: Sweden and Austria. (d) Training of Surveyors (95-97) contains three different projects: Continuation of LIMPE-project (EU-PHARE); the training for trainers in surveying; and later courses on the equipment and software purchased in the LIMPE-project previous phase. (e) Training of Cadastral Specialists (96-97). This Sub-Component is planned inside the same PHARE-programn, and part of it will be covered by Sweden and Germany. It is planned to introduce to the local cadastral specialists the goals of the modern cadastral system and the different ways to achieve them. (f) Support for development and implementation of the cadastral system in county offices and central cadastral office. The main elements for the county (decentralized) system are the interface to IPIS (alphanumeric cadastre) and data exchange between
 PIP I Page 5 of 9 counties, the central system and surveyors. The main elements for the central system are: design of dataflow (basic map, cadastral map, ground control points); interface to other registers; data exchange; and service for the public and private sector. (g) Mapping and cartography. Project plans cover the period from 1995 to 1999. The main activities are aerial photography, production of digital line maps, and orthophotos corresponding to the national map-production plans. Total budget is approximately 8,000,000 SEK. Financed by Sweden. (h) Photogrammetric and surveying equipment. This request includes 5 analytical Photogrammetric instruments, digitizers, plotters and printers, workstations for map editing, server, etc. to be delivered in 1996 and 1997. Total budget is approximately CHF 2.500.000. Financed by Switzerland. D. Component Description 15. The land reform component provides financing for land survey works, and for creating and densifying the National Geodetic Network. 16. The National Geodetic Network (NGN) will need reconstruction, and until the work on re-measurement of the NGN is finalized, the kinematic GPS receivers can be used for establishment of lower order networks, to coordinate the boundaries in one unified coordinate system. This work will allow the definition of the boundaries to the cadastral map to be of higher accuracy and will enable the surveying of the boundaries of large territories quickly and with high accuracy. The program is planned for four years, because in 1999, the measurements on the NGN will be completed or the network would be in the position that the majority of boundaries can be tied to the NGN. Within four years, 3,000 points will be measured, with the points measured using GPS technology available for future measurements. The estimated price for measurement of one point is US$470, and the total price of the component is US$1,410,000 (60% with World Bank financing for US$846,000). The most important idea of the component is not to re- coordinate the boundaries, but to get exact information in one unified system. All the work will be contracted out through local competitive bidding. 17. Cadastral Survey. The lack of adequate budgetary allocations, as well as fixed-price contracts to private surveyors (at one half of the market price), has contributed to a considerable slow down of restitution irelated to cadastral registration. Est-Survey, the state agency which had traditionally carried out parcel surveying, has been losing it's surveyors to the private sector. Indeed, there is no justification for parcel surveying still to be carried out by the public sector. A major component of the project - US$5,260,000 (60% World Bank financing for US$3,154,000) - therefore, is budgetary support for procuring parcel surveying using Local Competitive Bidding procedures. The contracts should be prepared in a way that the survey area is divided into attractive sized packages at the district level, with a cost amounting US$250,000 per contract. The choice and sequencing of areas should follow criteria identified above. According to the proposals and estimations in the frame of this project, approximately 7,800 rural properties (total area approx. 151,000 ha will be surveyed at cost of approximately US$35/ha.
