 PIP 2 Page 1 of 18 ESTONIA AGRICULTURE PROJECT PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION PLAN DRAINAGE REHABILITATION AND LAND MANAGEMENT COMPONENT I. The Component A. Objectives 1. The objective of the component is to assist in the restructuring and revitalization of Estonian agriculture. In line with this objective, the drainage rehabilitation and maintenance component focuses on action required to address critical needs resulting from neglect of drainage infrastructure during the transition period, and, after a one time rehabilitation, aims at handing over future operations and maintenance of the drainage system to the beneficiaries. Not all of the lands drained in the past should be rehabilitated due to both environmental and economic concerns. Hence, the project will focus on: (a) limited physical rehabilitation and maintenance of drainage systems on lands with high agricultural values and production potentials; (b) promotion and establishment of Land and Water Associations (LWAs) to take over ownership, management and financial responsibility for all on-farm systems (once rehabilitated) above the large main drains; and (c) reorientation of drainage research and training, emphasizing practical field application for cost effective maintenance. B. Component Description 2. The drainage rehabilitation component will consist of: (a) physical works on 60,000 ha over five years (less than 10% of drained farmland in Estonia), covering main drain rehabilitation and maintenance, rehabilitation and maintenance of collector drains, flushing and repair of subsurface pipe outlets entering collector drains, and selective tillage of compacted soils in the context of drainage improvement; (b) establishment of about 60 LWAs within the project area as formation of farmer groups to assume ownership of on-farm drainage systems and bear full responsibility for future operations and maintenance of the systems once rehabilitated; and (c) development of an adaptive research progmm to test innovative techniques for reducing and controlling maintenance costs. This project component also includes related training and studies. The drainage systems targeted for rehabilitation would be selected on the basis of social, technical, economic and environmental criteria. 3. The land management component consists of studies of, and equipment for, environmentally sensitive areas. Physical Rehabilitation of the Drainage Systems 4. The drainage systems in Estonia are extensive and critical to the future productivity of agricultural systems. Natural conditions for agriculture are far from optimal, primarily due to the short growing season
 PIP 2 Page 2 of 18 and the generally poor soil conditions. Although precipitation is fairly uniform between 570 and 720 mm/year, 65% of this rainfall occurs during a 5-month period from May to September with distinctive and critical peaks during short periods. On areas where natural drainage is inadequate during peak rainfalls, improved drainage through artificial means can extend the growing season for about a month by ensuring that groundwater table can be maintained at least 40 cm below surface. Drainage regulates moisture content and the depth of the groundwater table in the soils. Well drained lands can be planted earlier and harvested later, as waterlogging during rainfall peaks can be avoided and fields are dry enough for farm machinery to operate. In the context of the project, drainage rehabilitation will not be carried out on polders where submerged lands are drained for agricultural purposes. Drainage improvement will be primarily aimed at regulating the depth (below surface) of the groundwater table and moisture of the soils during critical periods, and thereby lengthening the growing season and increasing crop and pasture yields. 5. Transitional adjustments of the economy have resulted in a lack of funding for the maintenance of the drainage systems since 1988. Subsurface pipe systems will require selective flushing of lines to remove sediments and improve their proper performance, but rehabilitation work is important for restoring the capacity and depth of many open main and field drains. The cleaning of open drainage canals allows the free flow of subsurface pipes, thus maintaining their flow capacity. This work has to be done selectively, applying a set of criteria for prioritizing rehabilitation work and limiting the physical works to lands where environmental damage will be minimal and agricultural productivity can be profitable and sustainable. When maintenance is deferred too long up to a point, these drainage systems can no longer be maintained or rehabilitated, and reconstruction would be prohibitive in costs and economically questionable. Rehabilitation costs on lands targeted by the project are estimated to be about EEK 1,500/ha in 1995 financial terms, a small fraction (7.5%) of the full reconstruction costs of about EEK 20,000/ha. Selection Criteria for Drainage Rehabilitation Sites' 6. Selection of Areas. Drainage rehabilitation works will be undertaken on a total 60,000 ha, less than 10% of the existing agricultural lands that have already been drained. Drainage investments will be limited to rehabilitation works and will not involve investments in new drainage schemes. Sites where drainage rehabilitation would not be allowed include: * areas where fish and wildlife habitat is protected by Estonian environmental laws or rules; a poldered areas; * wetlands and estuaries with important wildlife or fishery values; * important native grasslands, buffer zones, and forest lands of special significance; * forest lands, until the forest strategy study is completed; 7. Potential sites would be screened individually and thoroughly, following a selection process to ensure that technical, economic, social and environmental criteria are fulfilled. Each of the following selection criteria shall be fulfilled before commencement of the drainage rehabilitation works: (a) Environmental Screening. Each drainage site shall be screened and cleared for The selection criteria have been specified in a supplemental letter to the loan agreement.
 PIP2 Page 3 of 18 rehabilitation by the Ministry of Environment or the respective District Environment Protection Department according to official regulations on the environmental screening criteria. The environmental screening process of the drainage rehabilitation program is elaborated in Annex 4: Environmental Aspects; (b) Soil Fertility. Each drainage rehabilitation site shall have an average soil fertility of no less than 40 points out of a scale of 100 based on the Estonian Soils Classification System. Soils with less than 40 points can only be included up to no more than 10% of each site area only when this substandard area must be included because of hydraulic design requirements. This condition aims for the best 25% of the drained farmlands, and practically excludes 75% of the existing drained farmlands; (c) Land use intensity. More than 70% of the agricultural land shall currently be utilized for agricultural purposes; (d) Conditions of the Drainage Systems. Each drainage site shall be assessed and approved for rehabilitation by the local amelioration bureau based on technical and engineering feasibility; (e) Development Costs. Rehabilitation costs of the drainage system, including civil works, designs, and supervision, shall not exceed EEK 1,500/ha in constant 1995 prices. This limit will exclude areas that require excessive and complex rehabilitation works; (h) Farmers' Participation. Farmers would have fonned LWAs in accordance with the Land Amelioration Law. The LWAs would: (i) make an application for the rehabilitation works; (ii) jointly approve the program of works together with the Amelioration Bureaux in the county; (iii) undertake maintenance of the system after it is rehabilitated, and ensure that on-farm drainage systems are effectively maintained; (iv) contribute 20 per cent of the physical rehabilitation costs through cash or labor prior to commencement of designs and civil works; and (v) meet the administrative and operational costs (such as expenses for meetings and book keeping) of the Association. (f) Land Tenure. Before commencement of the drainage rehabilitation works, no more than 5% of the agricultural land in any specific drainage site to benefit from drainage rehabilitation would remain state -owned or not leased to the private sector, with the exception of educational establishments. All lease contracts for state-owned agricultural land should be for a period of not less than 10 years. The extent to which land has been privatized and/or restituted will be considered2. This includes lands actually used by farmers, lands leased to farmers, and lands for which the owners opted for compensation. Further, all state-owned agricultural lands in a specific drainage site would be available 2 Cadastral surveys of drainage sites would be prioritized by the Land Board, and all lands benefiting from drainage would be registered in the cadastre prior to commencement of the drainage works at any specific site.
 PIP 2 Page 4 of 18 for sale or lease prior to the beginning of the drainage rehabilitation works on that site. The number of unresolved land disputes in each proposed site will also be used as a criteria for selection or non-selection, and will be evaluated through the proposed social assessments; and 8. In addition to the selection criteria, the rehabilitation and maintenance of open drains will be carried out using techniques to minimize environmental damages. These implementation criteria will include the following: * limiting excavation to design cross-sectional lines when channel cleanouts are carried out; having equipment work from one side of the channel wherever possible; * in view of-the need for sediment control, minimize damage to vegetation on channel side slopes; and * install instream sediment traps where needed. 9. Phasing of Development. Applying the physical criteria for area selection, the 12 Amelioration Bureaux (ABs) throughout the country (under the coordination of the Amelioration Unit in the Ministry of Agriculture) have preliminarily selected 42,000 ha of drainage sites located in 13 counties. To date, no areas have been preselected in Walga and Hiiumaa counties. These potential areas of 42,000 ha have been preselected primarily on the basis of their physical characteristics and potential, based on surveys conducted by ABs in 1994 and early 1995. Further preselection continues in order to identify more areas for inclusion into a pool of potential areas which will then go through a more rigorous selection process. It is planned that design work for the 60,000 ha development program will take place over 4 years covering: 3,500 ha in 1995; 16,500 ha in 1996; 25,000 ha in 1997 and the remaining 15,000 ha in 1998. Physical rehabilitation works for each site will be undertaken over a period of two years once design is completed. It is anticipated that 40% of the physical works will be done in the first year after design is completed, and the remaining 60% completed in the second year. Initially physical works will concentrate on main canals and collector drains, and subsequently on repairs of subsurface field drains. Design planning, LWA development and strengthening and physical works will take place over a period of 3 years for each site. With this time framework, the aggregate plan for physical works will be spread over a period of 5 years: commencing in the summer of 1996 with 1,400 ha; 8,700 ha in 1997; 19,900 ha in 1998; 21,000 ha in 1999 and the rest of 9,000 ha in year 2000. 10. Pilot sites. In the preselection process, the Amelioration Unit (AU) of MOA has identified two pilot sites for detailed assessment and environmental screening in 1995. These sites, namely Vigala (2,300 ha drained area) of Rapla county and Rannu (1,660 ha drained area) of Tartu county (should they meet the full requirements of the project, including the social preparation and LWA development aspects) would be thoroughly designed in 1995 using existing budget sources, followed by physical works in 1996 and 1997 under the project. It is anticipated that the total areas of these 2 pilot sites for rehabilitation would not exceed 3,500 ha. 11. Cost Recovery. The GOE plans to privatize the ownership, operations and maintenance of all farm drainage systems by handing over these systems to established LWAs. The Amelioration Law of May 1994 requires the formation of LWAs to take over the systems. Under the same law, ABs can levy cost recovery fees from users. LWA Membership is compulsory for every beneficiary of the specific drainage basin. GOE has determined that each LWA must agree to contribute (in cash or in kind) 20% of the cost of the one-round of selective rehabilitation works, while GOE pays for the rest of the upfront costs for
 PIP 2 Page 5 of 18 upgrading the systems to conditions that can normally be maintained. In return, the GOE would no longer be financially responsible for these on-farm drainage systems, and each LWA will have full ownership of its area-specific drainage system and bear full costs of the O&M responsibility. GOE is therefore effectively privatizing the drainage systems. However, the ABs will continue to be responsible for operations and maintenance of rivers and main canals outside the drainage areas, as the main canals often serve other users such as industries and municipalities. Cost recovery options for the maintenance of rivers and main canals are being considered by the AU, including: (a) the possibility of transferring the financial responsibility of this maintenance to the respective municipalities which can then recover these costs from beneficiaries through local municipal taxes, and; (b) direct levies to LWAs, and other users. Development of Land and Water Associations 12. The Government through the Amelioration Law of 1994 intends to privatize the ownership of existing drainage systems and transfer the responsibility of operations and maintenance of the systems to the farmers organized in Land and Water Associations (LWAs). The desirable direction for the management of the drainage system is to promote increasing farmer participation in system management and maintenance, with the Amelioration Bureaux (ABs) of the Government eventually playing a limited but important regulatory and oversight role. However, the realities of the current conditions warrant a transition arrangement until: (a) the ABs can effectively perform planning, regulatory, and emergency management functions; and (b) the LWAs can take over most of the system management functions at the local level above the main drainage channels. At present, there are four LWAs registered under the old Law of Associations predating the present Amelioration Law. Five to ten LWAs are anticipated to be registered in 1995. In the present context of Estonian agriculture, formation of such associations under the new law (which specifies financial and management responsibilities of farmers) will be progressive and will need a strong program of action for reasons given below. 13. Given the uncertainties surrounding land ownership and use, unstable input and output prices, and weak access to market intelligence, it does not appear easy for farmers to take over immediate responsibility for the drainage system. The assumption of management and financial responsibilities for the drainage system by the LWAs must be planned and developed in a sequential, participatory and evolutionary manner. A blueprint approach is clearly not desirable. Under these circumstances, it is planned that the Government will extend financial assistance to the LWAs for one round of selective rehabilitation of system, especially collector drains and related drainage systems, to prevent their further deterioration during the transition. Once rehabilitated to conditions where these systems would require normal and routine maintenance, the LWAs would assume full responsibility for subsequent operations, maintenance and periodic rehabilitation in the future. 14. Size and Functions of LWAs. The size of the Association would depend on the hydraulic area to be served, taking into account the size of each catchment area. It is expected that each Association would eventually cover about 1,000 ha and the Associations in the proposed project area for Bank support will likely number about 60. The primary responsibilities of the Association would be: (a) involvement in the planning, acceptance and implementation of rehabilitation works; (b) system maintenance of on- farm main drains, collector drains, and drain outlets; and (c) protection of the system against theft and destruction. To this end, the associations would be legally empowered to enter into contracts with repair and maintenance companies and borrow funds where necessary. In addition, the LWAs would provide an organized forum for farmers and external agencies for discussions and action on business planning, land improvement, and agricultural development issues including needs for advisory services or extension. The
 PIP 2 Page 6 of 18 LWAs would also, over time, organize training programs for their members in technical and financial management and investment planning. Relevant laws regulating the functions of the LWAs include: Land Amelioration Law (1994); Law on Associations (1992); Business Law (1995); and the Water Law (1994). 15. Internal Organization and Management of LWAs. While each LWA is responsible for establishing each own management, the Land Amelioration Law stipulates that each association must comply with the Law of Associations (1992). In general, a Chairperson is elected for a maximum period of 5 years, either directly by members (a case when the size of the LWA is less than 10 members) or through the LWA Board. Main responsibilities of the Chairperson include the overall functioning of the LWA, chairing the LWA Board, and chairing the annual meetings of the LWA. The LWA Board, in cases needed for larger LWAs, is elected by members. Annually, a third of the board members are to be replaced through an election. Jointly, the Chairperson and the Board are responsible for: (a) day-to-day activities, including supervision of farmers' contribution to the maintenance of the drainage system; (b) maintaining contacts with the Amelioration Bureau, the Municipality, the county office of the Land Board, the Farmers' Union, and other LWAs in the vicinity; (c) representing the LWA in meetings with third parties; and (d) organizing annual meetings where decisions are made on budget, administrative and operational matters. Voting is based on simple majority: one vote for each member (regardless of the size of the individual member's farm), unless otherwise specified in the constitution document of the association. The LWA, depending on size, will also have an Executive Secretariat consisting of technical staff who can deal with specific matters related to (for example) operations and maintenance, machinery, technical calculations and budgeting, preliminary designs and internal approval of works. The LWA may also employ administrative and accounting personnel on a full or part-time basis. Should the LWAs be larger than 30 members, an internal auditing committee is formed. 16. Procedure for LWA Formation. Once an initiative is taken to form an association by a group of farmers, most commonly a Task Force is formed for the preparation of a constitutional meeting and its subsequent series of discussions and consultations for the preparation of the Constitution Document of the association. This Task Force may consist of a few farmers, a representative from the Amelioration Bureau, and a representative from the Municipality. The LWA becomes a legal entity once registered at the county level. The registration process may take one week to a few months in cases where legal complication arises. Preparation for the Constitution Document requires active participation from farmers so that intemal rules and regulations of the association can be formulated satisfactorily. The Constitution Document must necessarily cover basic issues relating to: (a) level of membership entrance and annual fees; (b) definition of shared responsibilities and costs; (c) procedures for calculating and allocating shared costs; (d) collection procedures for shared costs; (e) description of the use of revenues and fees; (f) regulations to deal with non-payment of shared costs; (g) methods to deal with inflation; and (h) other administrative, financial, operational, management and organizational aspects of the association. 17. Training and Government Assistance for LWA Development. The formation of effective LWAs will require a major effort on the part of the Amelioration Bureaux. The experience of the present AB staff is largely technical, and until recently has not involved extensive participatory interaction with farmers. In some cases, the farmers too are new to the agricultural scene. It is important that the ABs participate actively in the formation of Associations because they would have to enter into several rounds of discussions and negotiations with members of the Association to come up with an agreement on and joint approval of the scope of rehabilitation works and responsibilities, prior to the commencement of physical works on each site. A systematic program of communication and training will be necessary to induce ABs to participate actively in strengthening the LWAs in using enabling legislation. To this end,
 PIP 2 Page 7 of 18 the staff of the ABs will need training and advisory assistance on the legal, organizational and financial aspects of farmers' organization. The GOE is committed to provide funding through its budget sources to: (a) train the staff of the ABs: and (b) recruit and train local consultants to serve as facilitators in the context of the LWA development and to assist in the formulation of various agreements between the Government and LWAs on the scope of rehabilitation works and shared responsibilities for each site. Training of the AB staff and LWA development facilitators is planned to commence in 1996 and continue intermittently until 1997. 18. In direct connection with LWA development, the Government provides assistance in three forms: (a) one-time assistance in the form of office equipment, software and supplies; (b) training and extension related to skill development of the LWA leaders and members for organizing and managing their day-to- day tasks (administration, accounting, technical operations and maintenance etc.); and (c) provision for start-up costs associated with formation of the LWAs including consultations, communications, legal paper work, right up to registration at the county level. The costs associated with these three forms of direct assistance to the LWA are estimated on average at EEK 90,000 in year 1995 financial terms per LWA. The GOE will provide the MOA with adequate budget allocations to cover these expenses. 19. Social Assessment. Studies and Technical Assistance. During the course of the project, the Amelioration Unit will commission three studies, namely: (a) a series of social assessment of target drainage areas; (b) clarification of the future role of the Amelioration Bureaux; and (c) a mid-term review of the LWA development program. These studies would be undertaken and phased appropriately to support the overall development of the LWAs and the targeting of project's initiatives and activities. Social assessment of target sites will be carried out early in 1996, and development of local skills to undertake this social assessment has started in the last quarter of 1995 (post appraisal, prior to project start date) with training provided through bilateral sources and World Bank's own resources (Fund for Innovative Approaches in Human and Social Development-FIAHS). While the criteria for area selection include the establishment of the LWAs and agreement by the associations to pay for part of the rehabilitation costs, there are a number of factors that can influence the achievement of this requirement: * Farmers' willingness to invest in drainage rehabilitation within a specific site may not be homogeneous; some farmers may be of pensionable age with a strong self-sufficient attitude to survival, while others are young and learning-by-doing people who are exchanging labor and machinery with their neighbors; * The level of experience among targeted farmers varies in light of new ownerships and categories of farmers. This factor influences adaptability to an emerging market system and ultimately farm restructuring; * The lengthy land restitution and privatization process underway has resulted in a mosaic of interim and recognized rights to land ownership and use, and this condition to some extent can inhibit long-term investments by farmers; * There is a need to tailor a package of assistance to farmers in order to support local initiatives; and local capacity for designing and delivering this package is essential for the sustainability of the investment strategy. 20. Considering the above factors, the MOA will undertake social assessments of households, with the objective of constructing social maps of the areas preliminarily selected for drainage rehabilitation and using these maps as inputs for the final area selection in accordance with technical, social, economic and environmental criteria.  PIP 3 Page I of 18 ESTONIA AGRICULTURE PROJECT PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION PLAN ADVISORY SERVICES COMPONENT L. The Component A. Objectives 1. The uncertainties pertaining to production, transformation, marketing and land ownership have created a large demand for agricultural extension advisory services. The objective of agricultural advisory services in Estonia is to induce voluntary change among rural people by: (a) transferring technology to and from farmers for sustainable agricultural production, processing, and marketing; (b) mobilizing and organizing farmers, rural groups and communities; and (c) educating farmers, building human resources and enhancing local capacity to generate, transfer and use information relevant to entrepreneurial and employment opportunities, technologies, and markets. B. Component Description Background 2. Pre-independence, agricultural technology and advice moved rapidly between the technical staff of research stations, state and collective farms, and the university. These highly specialized staff exchanged information regularly, each of them dealing with a narrow field of activity. Because markets and prices were predetermined and inputs provided at subsidized prices, questions on profitability, sustainability and competition did not arise. 3. As large farms have been dismantled, and small family farms as well as joint stock farms have emerged, the new farmers need advice and skills that respond to the needs of a market economy. Several extension systems used in European countries are being introduced and tested with bilateral assistance (Denmark, Germany, Netherlands). 4. There are about 700 people employed in Estonia who provide farmers with advice, nearly all on a part-time basis. Agricultural advisors are employed in the following manner: (a) the private sector (e.g. veterinarians, advisors from the processing industries, private consultants, input suppliers); (b) the public sector (e.g. staff from universities, research institutes, county staff of MOA);
 PIP 3 Page 2 of 18 (c) the media (mostly specialized print, and to a lesser extent radio and television); and (d) the farmers themselves (e.g. Farmers' Union with a staff of about 150, including 60 full- time advisors in the field, serving the family farms; or the Producers' Union mainly serving larger joint stock farms.) Present levels of public support for extension are low, representing about 0.05% of the agricultural GDP whereas many countries invest about 1 - 2% of the agricultural GDP in extension. 5. Who are the Estonian farmers. and what do they need? Roughly speaking, there are three types of farmers operating in Estonia: (i) viable farmers and farm managers; (ii) farms that need improvements to become viable; and (iii) the farms of questionable viability, including many part-time farms. Distinctions between the categories are blurred, but each category has different needs, that should be addressed --and paid for-- differently. The Project supports all three types of farmers. (a) The most viable farmers, including about 2,500 family farms and 1,200 joint stock farm managers need advice on production techniques, business skills including marketing and organization, and tactical advice, for instance to expand a herd, or switch crops. Given a proper introduction, many of them would be willing and able to pay for advice that benefits their individual enterprise (business development plans, soil tests, or loan application advice). The project foresees strengthening Private Advisory Services by supporting a Private Advisory Services Development Fund (PSADF) to provide these farmers with advice of their choosing. The fund has the dual purpose of providing eligible farmers with temporary and partial funding to buy advice so they get to appreciate the value of advisory services in increasing their income, while creating competition and enhancing quality among private agricultural advisors. (b) The middle categorv of farms, including about 10,000 family farms and 1,000 joint stock farms, mainly need technical and economic advice to make their current operation more profitable. Very often, those needs can be efficiently met through educational programs on milk quality improvement, general business skills, or pasture management, for instance. Such advice covers more public domain information and will continue to be carried out by the publicly funded extension services. The Project foresees strengthening publicly funded extension through: (i) more efficient delivery of advice; (ii) improved county inventories of current farming systems, problems and opportunities; and (iii) increased farner participation in priority setting. (c) Marginal and inviable farms. There are also an estimated number of 5,000 family farms and 1,500 joint stock farms that must leave farning or at least supplement their income from non-farming activities. These farmers need information on altemative employment, on legal matters pertaining to farm closure and land rights upon liquidation, and small and medium enterprise skills. The govemment is supporting rural information centers that aim at the most dynamic and risk taking segment of the rural population. The Project will support expansion of selected, rural information centers to include information on altemative rural employment, legal matters, and other information that specifically aims to ease the transition out of farming.
 PIP 3 Page 3 of 18 6. Critical success factors. The success of advisory services depends on: (a) quality advice that responds to the needs of the farmers; (b) early, strong and continued government support, including sufficient implementation capacity in a national task force on agricultural extension; and (c) effective public relations to inform farmers and the public at large of what to expect and what not to expect from extension. Long term success of extension will also depend on improvements in the curriculum of higher agricultural education in Estonia to ensure that the new private and public advisors have a stronger economic grounding, more practical and stronger communication skills and a broader general training; and on improvements in Estonian agricultural research to make it more responsive to farmers that operate in a competitive market. Farmers contribute to their advisory services. Most importantly, they help set the agenda, ensuring that the advice is relevant and the advisors held accountable. Second, the farmers are expected to pay for an increasing share of the PASDF and the operation and maintenance of the rural information centers. 7. Implications on govemment spending and farmers' contribution. Proposed support for Estonian advisory services is important, but limited, both in time and in scope. The Private Advisory Services Development Fund requires only an initial investment, because the farmers are expected to take over those programs over time. The Rural Information Centers will be partially self-financing over time, and only minimal public spending will be needed. The public extension service will remain a government investment in human resources, resulting in increased income and increased rural welfare. Chances to sustainably fund the public extension services are high, because of the important reduction in county-level field staff (from 6-7 per county to about 3-4). The Private Advisory Services Development Fund (PASDF) 8. This fund has the dual purpose of creating and developing demand for advisory services among the most viable farmers who are willing and able to pay for services; and creating competition among advisors to enhance their responsiveness to clients' needs. The program will be introduced in stages: a simple, limited pilot phase to start with, and a mainstreamed, more elaborated phase later on. It is estimated that about 3,000 farmers will need "private" advice, put it to effective use, and be willing and able to pay for it. It is planned that each eligible farmer would receive a grant from the PASDF of 2,000 EEK in 1996, which would cover a comprehensive business plan and ten to twenty visits a year. The Government would decrease the level of the annual grant and phase out the grant payment over 8 years. Assuming that one private advisor would have about 30 clients, his or her gross income from this scheme would be about 66,000 EEK, including the 200 EEK contribution of each farmer (in 1996). Such income would allow for a monthly income of 2,500 EEK and an annual operational budget that would include transport and communications of about 30,000 EEK. Over the 5-year Project period the mission estimates that the services of about 100 to 170 full-time equivalent advisors would be funded by PASDF. 9. In the pilot phase (1995-1996), funds from the budget, managed by the MOA, will be transferred from the MOA to the counties, based on shares of arable land. A county level steering committee will: (a) set criteria for fanner eligibility. Many counties will apply one or two simple criteria for eligibility, like 10 hectares of land, or 15 milking cows, for instance (b) inform farmers. Using direct mailing, public meetings and mass media carnpaigns, the county extension service will make the farmers in the county aware of the program, and of the exact procedures for them to follow in order to benefit from the program. In
 PIP 3 Page 4 of 18 particular, the county office, overseen by the steering committee, will: (i) inform the public at large of the program; (ii) invite eligible farmers to apply; (iii) register applicants; (iv) provide the applicants with a draft contract between the farmer(s) and the advisor(s) (c) oversee payment of advisors upon satisfactory completion of advisory services, as agreed in the contract between farmer(s) and advisor(s). The county-level steering committee would have one representative from the Farmers' Union, one from the Producers' Union, and one from the county extension service, and when formed, the heads of the LWAs in that county. The National Agricultural Extension Task Force has a major role to play in operationalizing the PASDF. The NAETF, through the staff of the MOA, will: (a) train the county extension staff; (b) oversee and encourage the development of extension tools, including simple computer software to assist farmers' cost/benefit analyses; (c) assist in the election of the steering committee; (d) train the county steering committees, including PASDF procedures, registration of private advisors, examples of successes of extension, Public Relations and public awareness campaigning. Public Extension Improvement 14. Publicly funded extension is ongoing in Estonia, but needs to be more demand driven, held more accountable by the farmers, make better use of the potential of existing resources and media, and work towards clearly defined and monitorable goals. The project aims to support the public extension through:
 PIP 3 Page 6 of 18 (a) simple, practical country extension inventories, providing minimum information who the farmers are: in terms of farming systems, trends in crop and animal yields, numbers and types of farmers, gender, part- or full-time, alternative income, age distribution. This information is presently fragmented or unavailable. The Project would provide training for staff to draft a simple, 1 -2 page questionnaire, and incremental operational funds for 2 staff in each county (one from the county office, one from the Farmers' Union) to carry out the inventory during 2 -3 weeks, and update it twice during the life of the project, during 1 week each. Office supplies have also foreseen, to present the findings, including simple maps of farming systems, in an attractive manner. (b) the use of rapid, participatory assessment (PRA) techniques to build consensus among farmers, researchers and extension staff on priorities for extension programs. The Project would provide training of staff in PRA techniques, incremental operation funds to carry out one assessment in each of the 15 counties by 6 persons (representing county office, Farmers' Union, Producers' Union, research, agri-business) during 3-4 weeks, to be repeated once after two years. In addition, the Project foresees 2 staff months of Technical Assistance to train selected staff in the use of PRA techniques, optimizing present techniques to build consensus among all major stakeholders. The expected output of the assessments would be a plan of action for the advisory services. Fanner needs would not be limited to production techniques, but also include needs for business skills, tactical advice and organizational aspects of farmer associations or commodity groups. (c) more coordinated production of extension materials, reducing present overlapping initiatives, while improving the quality and uptake by farmers. The project would support development and production of extension materials, training of staff and farmers, the development of extension tools, including simple farm management software packages. In addition, the MOA in the context of the Project would support incremental operational funding. (d) more efficient diffusion, through the training of extension advisors, and the use of the electronic and printed media. The Project foresees support for printing, diffusion on radio and television of relevant programs, training of trainers, study tours, and incremental operational funding. (e) more effective impact monitoring, through the use of agreed upon performance indicators. The Project would support training and incremental operational funds to collect, analyze, present and put to practical use, the findings, based on the performance indicators. For a comprehensive list of indicators, see Section IV of this project implementation plan. The Rural Information Centers 15. The government is supporting rural business centers that aim at the most dynamic and risk taking segment of the rural population. The Government aims to expand the scope of these business centers to include information on alternative employment and other legal and economic advice, that specifically aims to ease the transition out of fanning. The concept for the centers was inspired by the Scandinavian
 PIP 3 Page 7 of 18 telecottage model. The first telecottage opened in 1985 in Sweden. The following basic services are provided: (a) information services: access to regional, national and international databases; (b) data-processing services: access to computers with a selection of programs; (c) IT consultancies: the telecottage management is undertaken by an "IT caretaker", who also assists local businesses and organizations; (d) distance working: providing workstations for distance working; (e) education: open university type and online tutorials; (f) telecommunications: fax, e-mail, etc.; (g) village hall facilities: rooms and facilities for meetings, information. The project would support modest funding to provide equipment and support the development of training material. This initiative would require complementary technical assistance to assist in organizing these centers as joint-stock companies, initially with the local municipality as the major shareholder and progressively increasing the share of private ownership in subsequent years. The EU Phare program has been planned to include this type of technical assistance for a duration of at least a year. Also, GOE foresees expansion of the present advisory services with information on alternative rural employment, legal matters, and other information that specifically aims to ease the transition out of farming. To make indicators work, by making continuous and meaningful adjustments in content and method of the advisory services, three prerequisites must be considered. First, the different categories of farmers, with their farming systems, their constraints and their opportunities, must be known and understood well. This requires the detailed assessment, described above. Second, on the basis of this needs assessment, objectives need to be formulated in a participatory manner. Objectives should be formulated in terms of changed behavior of different target groups, by the different target groups. Third, extension managers must have the necessary technical and methodological knowledge and skills to make it work.

 PIP 4 Page 1 of 8 ESTONIA AGRICULTURE PROJECT PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION PLAN FOOD QUALITY CONTROL AND VETERINARY LABORATORY COMPONENT 1. The Component A. Objectives 1. The objective of the project component is to improve food quality and livestock quality standards to protect consumers and increase exports of food and livestock products. The project would support: (a) improvement of the National Veterinary Control Laboratory to control the quality livestock products and foodstuffs of animal origin for domestic and export markets; and (b) training for the operations of the food quality and veterinary control facility. The project would therefore provide Bank financing for the purchase of modem laboratory equipment and instruments and the necessary training for the State Veterinary Department in connection with the acquisition of this equipment, with specific objectives to: (a) set up a national program for the monitoring of contaminants and harmful residues in animal products and foodstuffs of animal origin; (b) improve veterinary control of infectious diseases, and ultimately the health safety features of foodstuffs of animal origin, in order to penetrate export markets and protect the health of foreign and domestic consumers. 2. This component are complemented by donor-funded parallel projects (partly ongoing) which provide technical assistance and training programs for developing food legislation, and institutional strengthening for the establishment and operations of modem food quality control facilities. B. Component Description Background 3. Currently, GOE plans to ensure rapid establishment of internationally accepted food quality control and standards in Estonia to meet both intemational and EU standards. At present, existing facilities are inadequately equipped. The State Veterinary Department depends on foreign laboratories for certain tests on residues and contamination. Since these tests must be taken at regular and frequent intervals, and results made available quickly for regular monitoring, the present situation is a constraint to the development of the local meat and food industry. Although Estonia has received export quotas and preferential tariff reductions on a number of food and animal products, because of the lack of internationally required food testing capability, export markets to EU countries remain inaccessible. 4. Legal Aspects. The State Veterinary Department is an independent unit under the administration of the Ministry of Agriculture. While the organization of the veterinary service and veterinary control is
 PIP 4 Page 2 of 8 prescribed in the Law on Veterinary Service, the Food Law specifies that the control of the quality of foodstuffs is conducted by several agencies including the National Grain Board, the State Veterinary Department, the National Health Board, the National Board on Standards, and National Customs. In accordance with the present rules prescribed under the Law on Veterinary Service, veterinary control covers aspects related to the quality of meat, meat products, milk, milk products, eggs, fish, honey and bee products, raw hides, wool and feather. Given the importance of the livestock sub-sector, this mandate represents a critical support to the overall development of the sub-sector. 5. Organization and Functions. The existing network of veterinary control consists of 15 County Laboratories and the National Veterinary Control Laboratory. County Laboratories are mandated to carry out basic biochemical, microbiological and serological tests to diagnose diseases, primarily of livestock, fowl and fish. These laboratories also establish the quality of animal products and foodstuffs of animal origin by means of chemical and microbiological analyses. Furthermore, the Veterinary Control Laboratory is mandated with the following main functions: (a) full diagnostic examinations of animal, poultry, fish and bee diseases; (b) chemical, physical, microbiological, organoleptic and toxicological analyses of animal products and foodstuffs of animal origin, feed and feed components, including evaluation of their quality on the basis of these analyses; (c) methodological guidance on diagnostics and procurement of relevant diagnostics supplies for County Laboratories; (d) examination and analysis of epizootological situation. 6. Present Constraints. To date, the present quality of animal products and foodstuffs of animal origin is assessed to a large extent on the methods prescribed under the GOST system of the former Soviet Union. Chemical and biological quality standards have been introduced in recent years in Estonia for milk, milk products and meat products. However, in a transition economy and as Estonia pursues an open market system, present standards need to be aligned with internationally accepted standards, including methods for establishing and monitoring compliance of these standards. For example, in the context of the trade agreement between Estonia and the European Union, EU standards require that for Estonian exports of animal products and foodstuffs into the EU, the content of various contaminants and potentially harmful residues must be ascertained. In addition, a program for monitoring and evaluation of these contaminants must be established and institutionalized in Estonia. Present facilities and their personnel are not equipped and trained to meet these international requirements. A number of guidelines will need to be established, especially those concerning: (a) the use of veterinary medicines; (b) instructions for testing animal products and foodstuffs of animal origin; (c) a system for sampling and transportation of samples; (d) a list of contaminants, their descriptions and methods for establishing their occurrence; and (e) instructions for dealing with cases where established limits for contaminants are exceeded. 7. Inaccessible Markets. As a result of the present inadequacy of the State Veterinary Department to meet the food quality testing requirements of the EU, potential export markets for certain products covered under the trade agreement cannot be realized. Although, the food quality of certain products would meet the EU standards, Estonia lacks the means of verifying this claim to serve as legal proof of
 PIP 4 Page 3 of 8 evidence. Potential market opportunities include 60% tariff reductions on agricultural products shown in Table 1. Table 1 Trade Agreement between Estonia and The European Union Food Items with 60% Reduction on Tariffs (metric tons) ITEMS 1995 1996 1997 TOTAL Bacon 800 900 1,000 2,700 Chicken meat 400 450 500 1,350 Skimmed milk powder 1,000 1,250 1,500 3,750 Butter 700 750 300 1,750 Cheese 700 750 300 1,750 Sausages and similar products 400 450 500 1,350 Food Quality and Veterinary Laboratory Equipment 8. The project provides funding for the acquisition of modern laboratory equipment for the improvement and development of the National Veterinary Control Laboratory, to support the main functions of this laboratory, particularly in the area of testing and control of contaminants and residues, as well as the diagnosis of diseases. This acquisition would be packaged to include major items as shown indicatively below: (i) Atomic absorption spectrometer (ii) Gas chromatograph (iii) Microwave for sample preparation (iv) Somatic sample counters (v) Colony counters (vi) Multi-purpose centrifuge (vii) Analytical balances (viii) Cryoscope (ix) Automatic Viscubator (x) Incubators (xi) Sterilization equipment (xii) Water filters
 PIP 4 Page 4 of 8 (xiii) Microscopes (xiv) Computers and software (xv) UV detector (xvi) and many more small equipment. 9. A complete list of equipment will be compiled by the end of 1995, and their specifications prepared. Although an indicative list of equipment has been prepared, this list will require some updating to fit with actual requirements, taking into consideration the inventory of availability and condition of some of this equipment. Training 10. In the context of the planned acquisition of new and modem equipment, the project will provide funding for training the staff, technicians and scientists of the National Veterinary Control Laboratory for the operations and maintenance of the equipment. Training on modem methods for detecting and measuring contaminants and residues are planned for about 6 persons for a duration of up to 3 months each. It is anticipated that the overall training program will be spread out over a year, and scheduled appropriately in line with the schedule of deliveries of the new equipment. Technical Assistance 11. Parallel projects already committed and funded separately by bilateral sources include: (a) assistance from Denmark (Danish Ministry of Agriculture) for developing the legislative framework for the quality of animal products; and (b) assistance from Finland for the development of monitoring and evaluation procedures related to food quality control and testing.

Implementation Arrangements A. Organizations Responsible for the Component 13. The agency responsible for the overall implementation of this project component is the State Veterinary Department. However, day-to-day operational and technical aspects are delegated to the National Veterinary Control Laboratory which will receive all equipment financed under the project. 14. The Project Implementation Unit (PIU)2 will assist in aspects related to procurement, loan disbursement, accounting, monitoring and evaluation, as well as administrative support. Detailed cost presented in Table 7 of Annex 6. Disbursement aspects are described in Section 11 (G) of the Staff Appraisal Report. 2 Terms of reference of the PII are presented in Annex 5. This PIU reports to the Inter-Ministerial Project Steering Committee.
 PIP 4 Page 6 of 8 B. Agreements between Borrower and Implementing Agencies 15. Agreements to be reached at negotiations between the Borrower and the implementing agencies are as follows: (a) The GOE will provide sufficient funding to the State Veterinary Department and the National Veterinary Laboratory to cover incremental operating costs associated with this project component. These costs include expenses for administration, operations and maintenance, and adequate staffing. C. Role of the Bank During Supervision 16. The food quality control and veterinary laboratory component will be supervised by Bank personnel (or designated consultants) in accordance with the proposed supervision plan summarized in Section III (F) of the Staff Appraisal Report. III. Implementation Plan A. Timebound Schedules 17. This project component, consisting of equipment acquisition and related training, is intended to be completed under the loan within a period of one year, and no later than 18 months from the project start-up date. Schedules of events under parallel donor activities are determined separately by individual donors. Basically, timelines to be monitored, are those relating to procurement packages described below, with timing shown in Table 2. B. Procurement Arrangements and Schedule 18. For all items funded through the loan proceeds, GOE agrees that: (a) it would apply procurement procedures which are consistent with the Bank's Guidelines for Procurement under IBRD Loans and IDA Credits (January, 1995), and Guidelines for Use of Consultants by World Bank Borrowers and by the World Bank as ExecutingAgency (August, 1981) for procurement of Bank-financed goods and consultant's services, and (b) that progress reports prepared by Government would include monitoring of the procurement process of the various aggregate amounts and ceilings. Procurement of technical assistance, equipment, and consultants for various studies under parallel co-financing arrangements would be carried out through tied procurement in accordance with procurement regulations of the respective donor countries. Table 2 summarizes the major procurement packages of this component and their schedules. Procurement for Bank-financed activities would be undertaken in the manner as described below: (a) Equipment (US $1.1 million). Laboratory equipment would be procured in two or three packages in accordance with International Competitive Bidding (ICB) procedures of the World Bank. When appropriate, the entire equipment would be grouped into a package to save administrative costs and gain benefits from economy of scale. The Borrower
 PIP 4 Page 7 of 8 would use Bank's Standard Bidding Documents as applicable. The application of domestic preferences would be in accordance with the requirements under Appendix 2 of the Bank's Guidelines. for Procurement under IBRD Loans and IDA Credits (January 1995), and expressed clearly in the bidding documents for goods. (b) Training (US $0.2 million). Consultants would be contracted to carry out the training program as identified under the project. Hiring of consultants would be in accordance with the Bank's Guidelines for Use of Consultants by World Bank Borrowers and by the World Bank as Executing Agency (August, 1981). doc.abstracts: The Agriculture Project's objectives are to increase rural incomes and stimulate the rural economy through rural entrepreneurship. To achieve these objectives, the project focuses on improving factor productivity and competitiveness of agricultural products by providing assistance for the: a) privatization of rural lands; b) privatization and rehabilitation of select rural infrastructure; and c) improvement of human resources skills for entrepreneurship in rural areas; d) introduction of new farming technologies consistent with transformed private agriculture; and e) improvement in food quality. Project components include: i) land reform which includes national geodetic network; cadastral surveying; and state-owned rural lands disposal policy and institutional strengthening; ii) farm drainage rehabilitation; iii) land use management; iv) agricultural advisory services; v) food quality control and veterinary laboratory; and vi) project management.
